A $J/\psi$ with momentum $100 \, \text{GeV}/c$ decays into $J/\psi \rightarrow e^{+} + e^{-}$, and it is assumed to be a symmetric decay (i.e., $e^{+}$ and $e^{-}$ have equal momentum in the laboratory frame). Determine the energy of the electron in the laboratory frame.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A muon has a mass of approximately $100 \, \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}$ and a rest lifetime of $2 \, \mu \mathrm{s}$. Assuming the Earth's magnetic field is sufficient to keep it moving in orbit, determine the energy required for the muon to complete a trip around the Earth.
solution:
For a muon to travel around the Earth, its lifetime in motion must be at least equal to the required time. Denote the muon's rest lifetime by $\tau_{0}$ and the Earth's radius by $R$, hence:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\tau_{0} \gamma \geqslant \frac{2 \pi R}{\beta}, \quad E_{\mu}=m_{\mu} \gamma \\
p_{\mu} c=m_{\mu} \gamma \beta=\frac{2 \pi R}{\tau_{0}} m_{\mu}.
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, the energy required for the muon to make a complete trip around the Earth is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\mu} & =\sqrt{p^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}=m_{\mu} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{2 \pi R}{\tau_{0} c}\right)^{2}} \\
& =100 \times \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{2 \pi \times 6400 \times 10^{3}}{2 \times 10^{-6} \times 3 \times 10^{8}}\right)^{2}}=6.7 \times 10^{6} \, \mathrm{MeV}.
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Explain the linear relationship between $\ln \lambda$ and $E^{-1/2}(\alpha)$ in $\alpha$ decay, and how this relationship reflects the change in the decay probability of $\alpha$ particles at different energies $E(\alpha)$. For example, how the change from $E(\alpha)=5.3\ \mathrm{MeV}$ to $E(\alpha)=7.7\ \mathrm{MeV}$ affects $\lambda$.
solution:
Assuming the speed of the $\alpha$ particle inside the nucleus is $v_{0}$, the number of times the $\alpha$ particle collides with the potential barrier per unit time is $v_{0} / R$, so the decay probability of the $\alpha$ particle per unit time is

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lambda=\frac{T v_{0}}{R} \\
\ln \lambda=-2 G+\ln \frac{v_{0}}{R}=-\frac{\sqrt{2 m} B R \pi}{\hbar}\left(E^{-\frac{1}{2}}-\frac{2}{\pi} B^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)+\ln \frac{v_{0}}{R}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $B=\frac{z Z e^{2}}{R}$ is a constant related to the nucleus. This is the required linear relationship between $\ln \lambda$ and $E^{-1/2}(\alpha)$ in $\alpha$ particle decay, where the second term is a logarithmic term and varies insignificantly compared to the first term. The above equation can be approximated into a simpler form

$$
\log _{10} \lambda=C-D E_{\alpha}^{-1/2}
$$

where $C$ and $D$ are constants related to the nucleus, and this equation is known as the Geiger-Nuttall law.

For two isotopes of ${}_{84} \mathrm{Po}$, the logarithmic ratio of their $\alpha$ decay constants is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log _{10} & \frac{\lambda\left({ }^{214} \mathrm{Po}\right)}{\lambda\left({ }^{210} \mathrm{Po}\right)}=0.434 \times \ln \frac{\lambda\left({ }^{214} \mathrm{Po}\right)}{\lambda\left({ }^{210} \mathrm{Po}\right)} \\
& =0.434\left[\ln \lambda\left({ }^{214} \mathrm{Po}\right)-\ln \lambda\left({ }^{210} \mathrm{Po}\right)\right] \\
& =0.434\left[\sqrt{2 m c^{2}} z Z \pi\left(\frac{e^{2}}{c h}\right)\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{E_{210}}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{E_{214}}}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \ln \frac{E_{214}}{E_{210}}\right] \\
& =\frac{0.434 \times \sqrt{8 \times 940} \times 2 \times(84-2) \pi}{137}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{5.3}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{7.7}}\right)+\frac{0.434}{2} \ln \left(\frac{7.7}{5.3}\right) \\
& \approx 10.55
\end{aligned}
$$

This means that their decay constants differ by more than 10 orders of magnitude.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: When a laser with a wavelength of 632.8 nm is incident on an HCl sample, a spectral line with a wavelength of 532.1 nm appears in the scattered light. This spectral line arises from a Raman scattering due to a vibrational transition and satisfies the selection rule $\Delta v= \pm 1$ ($v$ is the vibrational quantum number). Calculate the vibrational frequency of the HCl molecule, assuming the effects of anharmonic vibrations are negligible.
solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text{Since} \, \lambda_{0}=632.8 \, \text{nm}, \quad \tilde{\nu}_{0}=15803 \, \text{cm}^{-1}, \\
& \text{and} \, \lambda_{1}=532.1 \, \text{nm}, \quad \tilde{\nu}_{1}=18793 \, \text{cm}^{-1}, \\ 
& \text{therefore} \, \tilde{\nu}_{\text{vib}} = \tilde{\nu}_{1} - \tilde{\nu}_{0} = 2990 \, \text{cm}^{-1}, \\
& \text{thus} \, \nu_{\text{vib}} = c \, \tilde{\nu}_{\text{vib}} = 8.97 \times 10^{13} \, \text{Hz}.
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Estimate the equilibrium distance between the two nuclei of the "molecule" $\mathrm{H}_{2}^{+}(\mu)$, which is composed of $\mathrm{p}^{+} \mathrm{p}^{+} \mu^{-}$, where the $\mu^{-}$ particle has the same charge as an electron but a mass approximately 200 times greater than that of an electron. Assume that the role of the $\mu^{-}$ particle is similar to that of the electron in $\mathrm{H}_{2}^{+}$. It is known that the equilibrium distance between the nuclei in $\mathrm{H}_{2}^{+}$ is 0.1 nm.
solution:
In a diatomic molecule, the nuclei are held together by electrostatic forces, ensuring that the distance between nuclei is on the same scale as atomic radii. Using the Bohr model for estimation:

$$
\frac{r(\mu)}{r(\mathrm{e})}=\frac{m_{\mathrm{e}}}{m_{\mu}} \approx \frac{1}{200}
$$

Thus, $r(\mu)=\frac{r(\mathrm{e})}{200}=5 \times 10^{-4} \text{ nm}$.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A ground state hydrogen atom undergoes $\beta$ decay to become $\mathrm{He}^{+}$. What is the probability of it being in the 2S state?
solution:
According to the continuity of the wave function, at the moment of $\beta$ decay, we require:

$$
|1\mathrm{S}\rangle_{\mathrm{H}} = \cdots + a_{2}|2\mathrm{S}\rangle_{\mathrm{He}^{+}} + \cdots 
$$

And

$$
R_{20} = \left(\frac{Z}{2a}\right)^{3/2}\left(2-\frac{Zr}{a}\right) \exp\left(-\frac{Zr}{2a}\right)
$$

Calculating the coefficient $a_{2}$ as:

$$
a_{2} = \langle 2\mathrm{S} \mid 1\mathrm{S}\rangle_{\mathrm{H}} = \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{2}{a^{3/2}} \exp\left(-\frac{r}{a}\right) \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\frac{2}{a}\right)^{3/2}\left(1-\frac{r}{a}\right) \cdot \exp\left(-\frac{r}{a}\right) \cdot r^{2} \mathrm{d}r \int Y_{00}^{2} \mathrm{d} \Omega = -\frac{1}{2}
$$

Thus, the probability of $\mathrm{He}^{+}$ being in the 2S state is:

$$
W(2\mathrm{S}) = \left|a_{2}\right|^{2} = \frac{1}{4}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: An accelerator produces a beam of charged $\pi$ mesons, which have a rest average lifetime of $2.6 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~s}$. After traveling a distance of 10 m, $10\%$ of the $\pi$ mesons have decayed. Determine the kinetic energy of these $\pi$ mesons.
solution:
Previously, the momentum of the $\pi$ mesons was calculated as \( p = 1.71\ \mathrm{GeV}/c \). Therefore, the kinetic energy is

\[ T = E - m = \sqrt{p^{2} + m^{2}} - m \approx 1.58\ \mathrm{GeV} \]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The mass of the $J/\psi$ particle is $3.097 \, \text{GeV}/c^{2}$, and its width is $63 \, \text{keV}/c^{2}$. What is the average distance traveled by the $J/\psi$ particle before decaying, if its momentum is $100 \, \text{GeV}/c$?
solution:
The total width of the $J/\psi$ is $\Gamma = 63 \, \text{keV}/c^{2}$, and its natural lifetime is given by:

$$
\tau_{0} = \frac{\hbar}{\Gamma} = \frac{6.58 \times 10^{-16} \, \text{eV}\cdot \text{s}}{63 \times 10^{3} \, \text{eV}/c^{2}} = 1.045 \times 10^{-20} \, \text{s}
$$

The lifetime in the laboratory frame is $\tau = \gamma \tau_{0}$, where $\gamma = \frac{E}{m} = \frac{pc}{m}$ is the relativistic factor. The average distance traveled before decay is:

$$
l = \beta c \gamma \tau_{0} = \frac{pc \tau_{0}}{m} = \frac{100 \, \text{GeV}/c}{3.097 \, \text{GeV}/c^{2}} \times 1.045 \times 10^{-20} \, \text{s} \times 3 \times 10^{8} \, \text{m/s} = 1.012 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{m}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: In a cloud chamber filled with air at one atmosphere, a 5 MeV $\alpha$ particle shows a track 4 cm long. Given the nuclear cross-section $\sigma = 2.7 \times 10^{-25} \, \mathrm{cm}^{2}$ and the density of nuclei $n = 5.3 \times 10^{19} \, \mathrm{cm}^{-3}$, calculate the mean free path of the $\alpha$ particle.
solution:
The mean free path of the $\alpha$ particle is 

$$
\lambda = \frac{1}{n \sigma} = 7.0 \times 10^{4} \, \mathrm{cm}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A high-energy antiproton beam enters a liquid hydrogen bubble chamber with a length of \( l \). Let \(\sigma_{\mathrm{e}}\) and \(\sigma\) be the elastic scattering cross-section and the total cross-section, respectively. Assume both are independent of energy. For antiprotons with an incident momentum of \(\boldsymbol{p}\), determine the probability that they will eventually leave the bubble chamber without being absorbed, after undergoing any number of elastic scatterings.
solution:
The probability that an antiproton, after undergoing any number of elastic scatterings within the bubble chamber, ultimately leaves the chamber without being absorbed is given by

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} w_{n}(l) = e^{-(\lambda - \lambda_{\mathrm{e}}) l}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A radioactive source emits two independent types of radiation, \( A \) and \( B \). Within a determined time interval, the detector records 1000 counts of \( A \) and 2000 counts of \( B \). Given these conditions, find the statistical error of the measured ratio \( r=\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}} \).
solution:
Define the ratio as \( r=\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}} \). By differentiating both sides of the equation, we get:

\[
\frac{\mathrm{d} r}{r}=\frac{\mathrm{d} N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}-\frac{\mathrm{d} N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}
\]

Since the processes generating \( A \) and \( B \) are independent, we have

\[
\left(\frac{\Delta r}{r}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{\Delta N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\Delta N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)^{2}
\]

For Poisson distribution, \(\Delta N_{\mathrm{A}}=\sqrt{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\) and \(\Delta N_{\mathrm{B}}=\sqrt{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\). Therefore,

\[
\frac{\Delta r}{r}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}+\frac{1}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{1000}+\frac{1}{2000}}=3.87\%
\]

Thus, the standard error of \( r \) is

\[
\Delta r=r \times \frac{\Delta r}{r}=\frac{1000}{2000} \times 3.87\% = 0.020
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Assume a reservoir containing $10^{4}$ tons of water is built. The detection efficiency of the detector is $100\%$, and protons bound in the nucleus have the same decay rate as free protons. If the average lifetime of the proton $\tau_{\mathrm{p}}$ is $10^{32}$ years, how many decays are expected to be observed in one year?
solution:
Each water molecule $\mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O}$ contains 10 protons and 8 neutrons. The total mass of the protons is $\frac{10}{18}$ of the total mass of the water. The number of protons in $10^{4}$ tons of water is

$$
N=\frac{10}{18} \times 10^{7} \times 10^{3} \times 6.02 \times 10^{23}=3.34 \times 10^{33}
$$

The expected number of proton decays per year is

$$
\Delta N \approx \frac{3.34 \times 10^{33}}{\tau_{\mathrm{p}}} = \frac{3.34 \times 10^{33}}{10^{32}} \approx 33.4 \ \text{per year}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: If an atom is in the ${ }^{2} \mathrm{D}_{3 / 2}$ state, calculate the total electron spin angular momentum $|\boldsymbol{S}|$.
solution: $$ |\boldsymbol{S}| = \sqrt{S(S+1)} \hbar = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \hbar $$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: "Is the production of a single K meson with a neutrino $\nu$ evidence for the production of $\mathrm{D}^{0}$?" Is this statement correct? Please explain.
solution: No, it is not correct. Since a $\mathrm{K}^{-}$ meson contains an s quark, other particles such as $\Xi^{*}$, $\Omega^{-}$, or $\mathrm{K}^{*}$ can also decay into a single $\mathrm{K}^{-}$ meson; therefore, it does not necessarily indicate the production of a $\mathrm{D}^{0}$ meson.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The combination scattering of light on the HF molecule results in two accompanying lines with wavelengths of 267.0 nm and 343.0 nm for a certain spectral line. Calculate the vibrational frequency of this molecule. The atomic masses of H and F are given as 1.008 and 19.00, respectively.
solution:
Let the wave numbers of the two accompanying lines be $\tilde{\nu}_1$ and $\tilde{\nu}_2$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{\nu}_1^{\prime} &= \tilde{\nu}_0 + \tilde{\nu}_1, \\
\tilde{\nu}_2^{\prime} &= \tilde{\nu}_0 - \tilde{\nu}_1,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tilde{\nu}_0$ is the wave number of the original spectral line, and $\tilde{\nu}_1$ is the wave number of the vibrational band base line. By subtracting the two equations, the wave number of the vibrational band base line for the transition $v=1 \rightarrow v=0$ in the HF molecule is given by

$$
\tilde{\nu}_1 = \frac{1}{2} \left( \tilde{\nu}_1^{\prime} - \tilde{\nu}_2^{\prime} \right).
$$

Since the interaction force between the two atoms in the molecule can be approximately considered as a quasi-elastic force, the frequency of the light emitted during the transition between two adjacent vibrational energy levels is equal to the intrinsic vibrational frequency of the molecule, which gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu_1 &= c \tilde{\nu}_1 = \frac{c}{2} \left( \frac{1}{\lambda_1^{\prime}} - \frac{1}{\lambda_2^{\prime}} \right) = \frac{2.998 \times 10^{8}}{2} \left( \frac{1}{267.0 \times 10^{-9}} - \frac{1}{343.0 \times 10^{-9}} \right) \\
&= 1.244 \times 10^{14} \, \mathrm{s}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: If an atom is in the ${ }^{2} \mathrm{D}_{3 / 2}$ state, calculate the total orbital angular momentum of the electron $|\boldsymbol{L}|$.
solution:
$$
|\boldsymbol{L}|=\sqrt{L(L+1)} \hbar=\sqrt{6} \hbar
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: What is the kinetic energy of a neutrino \(\nu\) after the decay of a stationary K meson with a mass of \(494 \ \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}\)? The rest mass of the neutrino is 0.
solution:
In the rest frame of the K meson, by conservation of energy and momentum, the kinetic energies of \(\nu_{\mu}\) and \(\mu\) are respectively

\[
T_{\nu} = E_{\nu} = p_{\mu} c = 236 \ (\mathrm{MeV})
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A $\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}^{0}$ meson with a momentum-to-mass ratio of $\frac{p}{M}=1$ (mass $M = 498 \, \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}$) flies in the laboratory frame and decays into two $\pi^{+}$ and $\pi^{-}$ (each with mass $m = 140 \, \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}$). Determine the maximum longitudinal momentum of the $\pi$ mesons.
solution:
The longitudinal momentum of the $\pi$ mesons in the laboratory frame is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{l} & = \gamma\left(p_{l}^{*} + \beta E^{*}\right) \\
& = \gamma\left(p^{*} \cos \theta^{*} + \beta E^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, its maximum value (where $\cos \theta^{*} = 1$) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{l \max } & = \gamma\left(p^{*} + \beta E^{*}\right) \\
& = \sqrt{2}\left(206 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \times 249\right) = 540.4 \, (\mathrm{MeV} / c)
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
A relativistic proton loses 1.8 MeV of energy when passing through a 1 cm thick scintillator. What is the most likely mechanism?\\
(A) Ionization and excitation\\
(B) Compton effect\\
(C) Pair production\\
(D) Bremsstrahlung
solution:
Since protons mainly lose energy through ionization and excitation when passing through matter, for relativistic protons, the minimum ionization loss is approximately $\mathrm{d}E/\mathrm{d}x \approx 1 \sim 2 \,\mathrm{MeV}/\mathrm{g} \cdot \mathrm{cm}^{-2}$. The density of the scintillator is about $\rho \approx 1 \,\mathrm{g}/\mathrm{cm}^{3}$. After passing through 1 cm, the energy loss is

$$
\mathrm{d}E = (\mathrm{d}E/\mathrm{d}x) \cdot \mathrm{d}x \approx 1.8 \,\mathrm{MeV}
$$

The answer is (A).

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Consider the photoproduction reaction of $\pi^0$: $\gamma + \text{p} \rightarrow \pi^0 + \text{p}$, where the rest masses of the proton and $\pi^0$ are $m_{\text{p}} = 938 \, \text{MeV}$ and $m_{\pi} = 135 \, \text{MeV}$, respectively. The average energy of isotropic cosmic background radiation photons at 3 K is about $10^{-3} \, \text{eV}$. Determine the minimum energy of the proton required to produce this reaction when p and $\gamma$ collide head-on.
solution:
The average energy of a $\gamma$ photon from the 3 K background radiation is

$$
E_{\gamma} = \frac{3}{2} k T = \frac{3}{2} \times 8.6 \times 10^{-5} \times 3 = 5.8 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{eV}
$$

For a very high-energy proton, $E_{\text{p}} \approx p_{\text{p}}$. Using the relation $E_{\text{p}}^2 - p_{\text{p}}^2 = m_{\text{p}}^2$, the invariant mass squared when they collide head-on is

$$
S = \left(E_{\gamma} + E_{\text{p}}\right)^{2} - \left(p_{\text{p}} + p_{\gamma}\right)^{2} \approx m_{\text{p}}^2 + 2 E_{\text{p}} E_{\gamma} - 2 E_{\text{p}} p_{\text{p}} = \left(m_{\text{p}} + m_{\pi}\right)^{2}
$$

We obtain

$$
E_{\text{p}} - p_{\text{p}} = \frac{\left(m_{\text{p}} + m_{\pi}\right)^{2} - m_{\text{p}}^2}{2 E_{\gamma}} = \frac{m_{\pi}^2 + 2 m_{\text{p}} m_{\pi}}{2 E_{\gamma}} = 1.36 \times 10^{14} \, \text{MeV}
$$

Let $A = 1.36 \times 10^{14} \, \text{MeV}$,

$$
E_{\text{p}}^2 + A^2 - 2 A E_{\text{p}} = E_{\text{p}}^2 - m_{\text{p}}^2
$$

Hence,

$$
E_{\text{p}} = \frac{1}{2 A} \left(A^2 - m_{\text{p}}^2\right) \approx \frac{A}{2} = 6.8 \times 10^{13} \, \text{MeV}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: What is the threshold energy for the reaction $\gamma + \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{+} + \mathrm{n}$? How does $\sigma_{\mathrm{II}}(W)$ change with $W$ when $W$ just exceeds the threshold energy?
solution:
At the threshold reaction $\gamma + \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{+} + \mathrm{n}$, the momentum of the final state particles in the center-of-mass system is zero. At this time, the center-of-mass energy $W^{\mathrm{th} *} = m + m_{\pi}$. Initially, the proton is at rest, and the photon energy is $E_{\gamma}$, so the energy in the center-of-mass system is $W = \sqrt{2 m E_{\gamma}^{\mathrm{th}} + m^{2}}$, at threshold energy, we have

$$
\sqrt{2 m E_{\gamma}^{\mathrm{th}} + m^{2}} = m + m_{\pi}
$$

Therefore, the threshold energy is

$$
E_{\gamma}^{\mathrm{th}} = m_{\pi} \cdot \left(1 + \frac{m_{\pi}}{2 m}\right) \approx 150 \, \text{MeV}
$$

When $E_{\gamma} > E_{\gamma}^{\mathrm{th}}$, $\sigma(\gamma + \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{+} + \mathrm{n})$ increases rapidly with the increase of $E_{\gamma}$; when $E_{\gamma} = 340 \, \text{MeV}$, a broad resonance peak appears, whose resonance peak energy is

$$
E^{*} = \sqrt{2 m_{\mathrm{p}} E_{\gamma} + m_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} \approx 1232 \, \text{MeV}
$$

The width of the resonance peak is approximately

$$
\Gamma = 115 \, \text{MeV}
$$

This is called the $\Delta$ particle, and at the peak value, $\sigma \approx 280 \, \mu\text{b}$.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: In a cloud chamber filled with air at one atmosphere pressure, an $\alpha$ particle of 5 MeV displays a track 4 cm long. The average mass number of air molecules is $A = 14.7$. Assume the nuclear radius is given by $R = r_0 A^{1/3}$, where $r_0 = 1.2 \, \mathrm{fm}$. Calculate the cross section of the nucleus.
solution:
The cross section of the nucleus is

$$
\sigma = \pi R^{2} = \pi \left(1.2 \times 10^{-13} \times 14.7^{1/3}\right)^{2} = 2.7 \times 10^{-25} \, \mathrm{cm}^{2}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Considering a decay scheme diagram of a radioactive element as shown in Figure 4.13, design an experiment that primarily uses a high-precision beta spectrometer to measure the energy spectra of $\beta_{1}$ and $\beta_{2}$, and obtain $E_{1 \text{ max }}$ and $E_{2 \text{ max }}$.
solution: An experiment for precisely measuring the aforementioned decay scheme is to use a high-precision beta spectrometer to measure the energy spectra of $\beta_{1}$ and $\beta_{2}$, obtaining $E_{1 \text{ max }}$ and $E_{2 \text{ max }}$.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A high-energy accelerator produces two proton beams moving in opposite directions, which collide head-on. Each beam has an energy of 30 GeV. Please calculate the total energy of the collision in the center-of-mass system.
solution:
In the center-of-mass system, the total momentum of the colliding beams is zero, and the two particle beams are almost head-on colliding. The square of the invariant mass is given by

$$
s=\left(E_{\mathrm{p}_{1}}+E_{\mathrm{p}_{2}}\right)^{2} \approx \left(2 E_{\mathrm{p}}\right)^{2}, \quad \sqrt{s}=2 E_{\mathrm{p}}=60 \mathrm{GeV}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Due to the observation in experiments of narrow, long-lived states $J/\psi, \psi^{\prime}$, a new charm quantum number was introduced. Additionally, states with large mass $(\gamma, \gamma^{\prime}, \cdots)$, with a mass of approximately $\sim 10 \mathrm{GeV}$, were observed. Experimentally, these states were discovered through their decay into lepton pairs. Therefore, a new quantum number $b$ (beauty) was introduced.

(1) Roughly estimate the mass of the $b$ quark;
solution:
(1) By neglecting the binding energy of the $b$ quark, the mass of the $b$ quark is

$$
m_{\mathrm{b}} = \frac{1}{2} M_r \approx 5 \mathrm{GeV}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Consider the following isospin-conserving reactions occurring in the states of $I=\frac{3}{2}$ ( resonance) and $I=\frac{1}{2}$ (N* resonance). Calculate the cross-section ratio $\sigma_{1}:\sigma_{2}:\sigma_{3}$ at the energies corresponding to the  resonance and N* resonance. At the resonance energy, other isospin state effects can be neglected. $I_{\pi}=1, I_{\mathrm{N}}=\frac{1}{2}$.
1. $\pi^{+} \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \mathrm{p}$
2. $\pi^{-} \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{-} \mathrm{p}$
3. $\pi^{-} \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{0} \mathrm{n}$
solution:
The decay of the charged intermediate boson

\[
\mathrm{W}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{+} + \nu
\]

The Feynman diagram is shown in Figure 3.20. In the diagram, \(\varepsilon^{\mu}(k)\) is the vector wave function of the \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) particle, where \(\mu=0,1,2,3\). \(\nu\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{2}\right)\) and \(\overline{\mathrm{u}}\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{1}\right)\) are the Dirac wave functions for the positron and neutrino, respectively. The interaction matrix element and its Hermitian conjugate are:

\[
M_{\mathrm{W} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{+}}=\frac{-\mathrm{i}g}{\sqrt{2}} \overline{\mathrm{u}}\left(p_{1}\right) \gamma_{\mu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \nu\left(p_{2}\right) \cdot \varepsilon^{\mu}(k)
\]

\[
M_{\mathrm{W} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{+}}^{+}=\frac{\mathrm{i} g}{\sqrt{2}} \bar{\nu}\left(p_{2}\right) \gamma_{\nu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \mathrm{u}\left(p_{1}\right) \cdot \varepsilon^{\nu}(k)
\]

where \(\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right)\) is the left-handed projection operator. We obtain the square of the decay matrix element:

\[
|M|^{2}=M M^{+}=\frac{g^{2}}{2} \bar{\nu}\left(p_{2}\right) \gamma_{\nu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \mathrm{u}\left(p_{1}\right) \overline{\mathrm{u}}\left(p_{1}\right) \gamma_{\mu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \nu\left(p_{2}\right) \cdot \varepsilon^{\mu}(k) \cdot \varepsilon^{\nu}(k)
\]

where

\[
\mathrm{u} \overline{\mathrm{u}} = \not{p}_1 + m
\]

\[
\nu \bar{\nu} = \not{p}_2 - m
\]

\[
m_{\nu} \approx m_{\mathrm{e}} \approx 0
\]

When summing over the unpolarized states of \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\), we get:

\[
\sum_{\lambda=1}^{3} \varepsilon_{\lambda}^{\mu}(k) \varepsilon_{\lambda}^{\nu}(k)-\varepsilon_{0}^{\mu}(k) \varepsilon_{0}^{\nu}(k)=-g^{\mu \nu}
\]

Substituting into the above expression:

\[
|M|^{2} =\frac{g^{2}}{2}\left(-g^{\mu \nu}\right) \bar{\nu}\left(p_{2}\right) \gamma_{\nu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \gamma_{\mu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \nu\left(p_{2}\right)
\]

\[
=-\frac{g^{2}}{2} g^{\mu \nu} \bar{\nu}\left(p_{2}\right) \gamma_{\nu \mu_{1}} \gamma_{\mu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \nu\left(p_{2}\right)
\]

where \(\bar{\nu} \hat{\theta} \nu\) as a bilinear spinor form is a commutative constant, so we can take the trace of this number:

\[
\left|M\right|^{2} =-\frac{g^{2}}{2} g^{\mu \nu} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\gamma_{\nu \not_{1}} \gamma_{\mu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} \cdot \nu \bar{\nu}\right]
\]

\[
=-\frac{g^{2}}{2} g^{\mu \nu} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\gamma_{\nu \digamma_{1}} \cdot \gamma_{\mu} \cdot \frac{1-\gamma_{5}}{2} p_{2}\right]
\]

\[
=-\frac{g^{2}}{2} g^{\mu \nu} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\gamma_{\nu \mu_{1}} \gamma_{\mu} \gamma_{2} \cdot \frac{1+\gamma_{5}}{2}\right]
\]

\[
=-\frac{g^{2}}{4}\left\{4 g^{\mu \nu}\left[p_{1 \nu} p_{2 \mu}-g_{\mu \nu}\left(p_{1} \cdot p_{2}\right)+p_{1 \mu} p_{2 \nu}\right]+4(-\mathrm{i}) g^{\mu \nu} \varepsilon_{\nu \not 1^{\mu} \not \boldsymbol{p}_{2}}\right\}
\]

Here, \(\not=\gamma_{\mu} p^{\mu}\), in the last term, \(g^{\mu \nu}\) is symmetric, \(\varepsilon_{\nu \mu_{1} \mu_{2}}\) is antisymmetric, so this term is zero. We arrive at a simple relation:

\[
|M|^{2}=-g^{2}\left(2 p_{1} \cdot p_{2}-g^{\mu \nu} g_{\mu \nu} p_{1} \cdot p_{2}\right)
\]

Using the relation:

\[
k = p_{1} + p_{2}
\]

\[
\left(p_{1} + p_{2}\right)^{2} = p_{1}^{2} + p_{2}^{2} + 2 p_{1} p_{2} = 2 p_{1} p_{2} = k^{2} = M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}
\]

\[
g^{\mu \nu} g_{\mu \nu} = g_{\nu}^{\nu} = \delta_{\nu}^{\nu} = 4
\]

Substituting this into the equation above, we finally obtain the squared decay matrix element:

\[
|M|^{2} = 2 g^{2} p_{1} \cdot p_{2} = g^{2} M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}
\]

For a two-body decay of \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\), we have

\[
\mathrm{d} \Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}} = \frac{1}{N_{\mathrm{W}}} \cdot \frac{1}{32 \pi^{2}} |M|^{2} \cdot \frac{\left|\boldsymbol{p}_{1}\right|}{M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} \Omega = \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{32 \pi^{2}} g^{2} M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2} \cdot \frac{\left(\frac{M_{\mathrm{W}}}{2}\right)}{M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} \Omega = \frac{g^{2} M_{\mathrm{W}}}{192 \pi^{2}} \mathrm{~d} \Omega
\]

where \(N_{\mathrm{W}}=3\) is the factor for averaging over the initial spin states of \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\). In the rest frame of \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\), we have \(\left|p_{1}\right|=\left|p_{2}\right|=\frac{1}{2} M_{\mathrm{W}}\).

Performing the angular integration gives

\[
\Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}} = \int \mathrm{d} \Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}} = \int_{4 \pi} \frac{g^{2} M_{\mathrm{W}}}{192 \pi^{2}} \mathrm{~d} \Omega = \frac{g^{2} M_{\mathrm{W}}}{48 \pi}
\]

Using the relation

\[
\frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{g^{2}}{8 M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}} \Rightarrow g^{2}=\frac{8 G_{F} M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}}{\sqrt{2}}
\]

Finally, the partial width for the decay of the charged intermediate boson \(\mathrm{W}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{+}+\nu\) is obtained as

\[
\Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}}=\frac{G_{\mathrm{F}} M_{\mathrm{W}}^{3}}{6 \pi \sqrt{2}} \approx \frac{1.17 \times 10^{-5} \times 82^{3}}{6 \pi \sqrt{2}} \approx 0.242 (\mathrm{GeV}) = 242 (\mathrm{MeV})
\]

Of course, we can also roughly estimate the decay width using dimensional analysis from Fermi's theory. The decay width is proportional to the Fermi constant \(G_{\mathrm{F}} \approx 1.17 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{GeV}^{-2}\). At this energy scale, the masses of quarks and leptons can be neglected, leaving the only energy scale as the vector boson's mass \(M_{\mathrm{W}}\). Hence, \(\Gamma \approx G_{\mathrm{F}} M_{\mathrm{W}}^{x}\) with dimensional analysis: \([\Gamma]=\mathrm{M}\), it should have a term proportional to the third power of the vector boson's mass \(M_{\mathrm{W}}\), i.e., \(x=3\),

\[
\Gamma_{\mathrm{W} \rightarrow \mathrm{ev}} \approx G_{\mathrm{F}} M_{\mathrm{W}}^{3} = 1.17 \times 10^{-5} \times 82^{3} \approx 6.45 (\mathrm{GeV})
\]

This is only a rough estimate, which, compared to our calculation above, misses the factor \(6 \pi \sqrt{2} \approx 26.7\).

Experimental value: \(\Gamma=(2.12 \pm 0.05)\) GeV, \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}} / \Gamma=0.107 \pm 0.002\). From this, \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}} \approx 227\) MeV is obtained. The precise calculated value aligns well with current experimental results, while the rough estimate differs significantly from the experimental value.

Neglecting the masses of leptons and quarks, we can derive:

\[
\Gamma_{\mathrm{ud}}=\Gamma_{\mathrm{c} \overline{\mathrm{s}}} \approx 3 \Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}}
\]

where factor 3 is the contribution from quark colors. The total width includes two quark generations and three lepton generations, but the top quark is too heavy for \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) to decay into. Therefore, considering two quark generations and three lepton generations:

\[
\Gamma=9 \Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}}=9 \times 242=2178 (\mathrm{MeV})
\]

The lifetime of \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) is given by

\[
\tau = \Gamma^{-1} \approx \frac{1}{2178} = 4.6 \times 10^{-4} (\mathrm{MeV}^{-1}) = 4.6 \times 10^{-4} \times 6.6 \times 10^{-22} = 3.04 \times 10^{-25} (\mathrm{s})
\]

where \( \mathrm{MeV}^{-1} = 6.6 \times 10^{-22} \mathrm{s} \) is used.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: One possible mode of proton decay is $\mathrm{p} \rightarrow \pi^{0}+\mathrm{e}^{+}$. The $\pi^{0}$ immediately (in $10^{-16} \ \mathrm{s}$) decays into two photons: $\pi^{0} \rightarrow \gamma+\gamma$. Calculate the maximum and minimum photon energy resulting from the decay of a proton at rest $\left(m_{\mathrm{p}}=938 \ \mathrm{MeV}/\mathrm{c}^{2}, m_{\mathrm{e}}=0.511 \ \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}, m_{\pi}=135 \ \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}\right)$.
solution:
In the rest frame of the proton, the laws of energy and momentum conservation require

$$
\begin{gathered}
m_{\mathrm{p}} = E_{\pi} + E_{\mathrm{e}^{+}} \\
p_{\pi} = p_{\mathrm{e}^{+}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Using $E^{2} = m^{2} + p^{2}$, we obtain

$$
E_{\pi} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} + m_{\pi}^{2} - m_{\mathrm{e}}^{2}}{2 m_{\mathrm{p}}} = \frac{938^{2} + 135^{2} - 0.511^{2}}{2 \times 938} \approx 479 \ \mathrm{MeV}
$$

In the rest frame of the $\pi^{0}$, the energy of each $\gamma$ photon is

$$
E^{*} = \frac{m_{\pi^{0}}}{2}
$$

The Lorentz factor and velocity of the $\pi^{0}$ are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\gamma_{\pi} = \frac{479}{135} = 3.548 \\
\beta_{\pi} = \sqrt{1 - \frac{1}{\gamma_{\pi}^{2}}} = 0.9595
\end{gathered}
$$

Using the Lorentz transformation between the center-of-mass system and the laboratory system, we have

$$
E_{\gamma} = \gamma_{\pi} \left(E^{*} + \beta_{\pi} p^{*} \cos \theta^{*}\right) = \frac{m_{\pi}}{2} \gamma_{\pi} \left(1 + \beta_{\pi} \cos \theta^{*}\right) = \frac{E_{\pi}}{2} \left(1 + \beta_{\pi} \cos \theta^{*}\right)
$$

When $\theta^{*} = 0$, the photon energy is maximum

$$
\left(E_{\gamma}\right)_{\max} = \frac{E_{\pi}}{2} \left(1 + \beta_{\pi}\right) = \frac{479}{2}(1 + 0.9595) \approx 469.3 \ \mathrm{MeV}
$$

When $\theta^{*} = 180^{\circ}$, the photon energy is minimum

$$
\left(E_{\gamma}\right)_{\min} = \frac{E_{\pi}}{2} \left(1 - \beta_{\pi}\right) = \frac{479}{2}(1 - 0.9595) \approx 9.7 \ \mathrm{MeV}
$$

problem: A $\mu^{+}$ muon decays into a positron and two neutrinos $\mu^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{+}+\nu_{\mathrm{e}}+\bar{\nu}_{\mu}$, with an average lifetime of $2 \mu \mathrm{s}$. If a stationary $\mu^{+}$ muon's polarization along the $z$-axis in some coordinate system is $P$, and only the positrons from $\mu^{+}$ decay with maximum energy are observed, the angular distribution of these emitted positrons is given by $I \cos \theta \mathrm{~d} \Omega=(1+P \cos \theta) \frac{\mathrm{d} \Omega}{4 \pi}$, where $\theta$ is the angle between the positron emission direction and the $z$-axis, and $\mathrm{d} \Omega$ is the solid angle element in the direction of positron emission. Assume $P=+1$, what is the probability that, among the observed 6 positrons, 3 are emitted towards the forward hemisphere $(\cos \theta>0)$ and 3 towards the backward hemisphere $(\cos \theta<0)$?
solution:
Since $\mathrm{d} \Omega = 2 \pi \mathrm{~d}(\cos \theta)$, for any value of $P$, the probability of positrons being emitted forwards is

$$
P_{\mathrm{f}} = 2 \pi \int_{0}^{1} \frac{(1+P \cos \theta) \mathrm{d} \cos \theta}{4 \pi} = \frac{1}{2} \left(1 + \frac{P}{2}\right)
$$

The probability of being emitted backwards is

$$
P_{\mathrm{b}} = 2 \pi \int_{-1}^{0} \frac{(1+P \cos \theta) \mathrm{d} \cos \theta}{4 \pi} = \frac{1}{2} \left(1 - \frac{P}{2}\right)
$$

If we have $N$ positrons, where the number emitted forward is $N_{\mathrm{f}}$ and the number emitted backward is $N_{\mathrm{b}}$, the probability distribution follows a binomial distribution:

$$
W = \frac{N!}{N_{\mathrm{f}}! N_{\mathrm{b}}!} \left(P_{\mathrm{f}}\right)^{N_{\mathrm{f}}} \left(P_{\mathrm{b}}\right)^{N_{\mathrm{b}}}
$$

For $P = 1, P_{\mathrm{f}} = \frac{3}{4}, P_{\mathrm{b}} = \frac{1}{4}, N = 6, N_{\mathrm{f}} = N_{\mathrm{b}} = 3$, this probability is

$$
W = \frac{6!}{3!3!} \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{3} \left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3} = 20 \times \frac{27}{4096} = 0.132
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Neglecting non-conservation, the neutral \( \mathrm{K}^{0} \) meson \( \left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle \) and \( \left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle \) can be expressed in terms of the \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle \) and \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle \) states,

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right), \\
& \left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle-\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right).
\end{aligned}
\]

\( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle \) and \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle \) are states with lifetimes \( \tau_{\mathrm{L}}=\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{L}}} \) and \( \tau_{\mathrm{S}}=\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{S}}} \) respectively, and they also have different rest masses, i.e., \( m_{\mathrm{L}} c^{2} \neq m_{\mathrm{S}} c^{2} \). Suppose a meson is in the state \( |\Psi(t=0)\rangle=\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle \) at \( t=0 \). Find the probability \( P_{0}(t) \) that the system is in the \( \left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle \) state at time \( t \).
solution:
At \( t=0 \), the state is

\[
\Psi(0)=\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right)
\]

At time \( t \), the state is

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \Psi(t)=\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} H t} \Psi(0)=\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} H t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2}\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2}\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left\{\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle+\left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle\right)+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle-\left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle\right)\right\} \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2}+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2}\right)\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle+\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2}-\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2}\right)\left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle\right]
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus, \( P_{0}(t) \) is

\[
P_{0}(t)=\frac{1}{4}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t}+\mathrm{e}^{-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-\left(\gamma_{\mathrm{L}}+\gamma_{\mathrm{S}}\right) t / 2} \cos \left((m_{\mathrm{L}}-m_{\mathrm{S}}) t\right)\right]
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Why is the probability of the decay channel $\mathrm{K}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-}$ approximately twice that of the decay channel $\mathrm{K}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{0} \pi^{0}$?
solution:
Assuming the probabilities of the two decay channels differ primarily due to the different coupling in isospin space, their decay rate ratio can be calculated. These decay probabilities are proportional to the isospin part of the matrix elements, which can be given by Clebsch-Gordan coefficients.

For the decay channel $\mathrm{K}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{0} \pi^{0}$, it is

$$
\left|\left\langle\pi^{0} \pi^{0} \mid I=0, I_{z}=0\right\rangle\right|^{2}
$$

Whereas for $\mathrm{K}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-}$, it is

$$
\left|\left\langle\pi^{+} \pi^{-} \mid I=0, I_{z}=0\right\rangle\right|^{2}
$$

In isospin space, the expressions for $\pi^{0} \pi^{0}$ and $\pi^{+} \pi^{-}$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\pi^{0} \pi^{0}\right\rangle=\left|1,1,0,0\right\rangle \\
& \left|\pi^{+} \pi^{-}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|1,1,1,-1\right\rangle+\left|1,1,-1,1\right\rangle\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, for the system $\left|\pi^{+} \pi^{-}\right\rangle$, we must write it as a symmetric combination because they are bosons. As discussed in solution (1), the wave function must be symmetric in the rest frame. Assuming the decay of the $\pi^{0} \pi^{0}$ and $\pi^{+} \pi^{-}$ states is only due to their different isospin parts, we use the given Clebsch-Gordan coupling coefficients to obtain the ratio of the probabilities of the two decay channels:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\Gamma\left(\pi^{+} \pi^{-}\right)}{\Gamma\left(\pi^{0} \pi^{0}\right)} & =\frac{\frac{1}{2}|\left(\langle 1,1,1,-1 \mid 0,0\rangle+\langle 1,1,-1,1 \mid 0,0\rangle\right)|^{2}}{|\langle 1,1,0,0 \mid 0,0\rangle|^{2}} \\
& =\frac{\frac{1}{2} \cdot|2 \sqrt{1 / 3}|^{2}}{|-\sqrt{1 / 3}|^{2}}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

The factor of 2 comes from the isospin coupling formula, reflecting the fact that the final state of two $\pi^{0}$ are identical particles, while $\pi^{+}$ and $\pi^{-}$ are not identical particles.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Estimate the ratio of the following decay rates and specify the selection rules applied ("fundamental" or phenomenological). Also, indicate whether each decay is strong, weak, or electromagnetic. If possible, express the results in terms of fundamental constants (such as \(G, \alpha, \theta_{\mathrm{c}}, m_{\mathrm{k}}\), etc.). Assume that the strong interaction has a unit strength.
(1) \(\frac{\mathrm{K}^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{0}}{\mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{s}}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-}}\).
solution:
The decay \(\mathrm{K}^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{0}\) is a weak decay. Non-leptonic weak decays require: \(\Delta I=\frac{1}{2}\). Given that \(I(\mathrm{~K})=\frac{1}{2}\), the \(2 \pi\) system's \(I\) must be 0 or 1. However, according to the generalized Pauli principle, the total wave function of the \(\pi\) system must be symmetric. Conservation of total angular momentum requires \(J\left(\pi^{+} \pi^{0}\right)=J(\mathrm{~K})=0\), and since the spin of \(\pi\) is zero, we find \(l=0\). The spatial and spin parts are symmetric, necessitating that the isospin wave function must also be symmetric. The possible isospin values for the \(\pi^{+} \pi^{0}\) system are 0 and 2. To satisfy both conditions, it must be \(I\left(\pi^{+} \pi^{0}\right)=0\). However, given that \(I_{3}\left(\pi^{+} \pi^{0}\right)=1, I \geqslant I_{3}\) requires \(I\left(\pi^{+} \pi^{0}\right) \geqslant 1\), implying the decay \(\mathrm{K}^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{0}\) does not follow the \(\Delta I=\frac{1}{2}\) rule, making it forbidden. In contrast, \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{s}}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-}\) obeys the \(\Delta I=\frac{1}{2}\) rule, therefore

\[
\frac{\mathrm{K}^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{0}}{\mathrm{~K}_{\mathrm{s}}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-}} \ll 1
\]

Assuming that in K meson decay, the change in isospin can have \(\Delta I=\frac{1}{2}\) and \(\frac{3}{2}\) possibilities, with their amplitudes denoted as \(A_{0}\) and \(A_{2}\) respectively. By using K meson decay observations, one can determine the relative values of \(A_{0}\) and \(A_{2}\). Experimentally, it yields

\[
\frac{\Gamma\left(\mathrm{K}^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{0}\right)}{\Gamma\left(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{s}}^{0} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-}\right)}=\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{A_{2}}{A_{0}}\right)^{2} \approx 1.5 \times 10^{-3}
\]

Thus yielding

\[
\frac{A_{2}}{A_{0}} \approx 4.47 \%
\]

problem:
Currently, there are two mechanisms used to explain the formation of solar energy through nuclear fusion: the carbon-nitrogen cycle and the hydrogen-hydrogen cycle. In the carbon-nitrogen reaction chain, what fusion material is actually consumed?

(A) Carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen  
(B) Carbon, nitrogen, helium, hydrogen  
(C) Helium, hydrogen  
(D) Hydrogen
solution:
One of the thermonuclear reaction chains inside the Sun is the carbon-nitrogen reaction chain. The reaction process is as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
{ }^{12} \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{p} &\rightarrow { }^{13} \mathrm{N}+\gamma \\
{ }^{13} \mathrm{N} &\rightarrow { }^{13} \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{e}^{+}+\nu_{\mathrm{e}} \\
{ }^{13} \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{p} &\rightarrow { }^{14} \mathrm{N}+\gamma \\
{ }^{14} \mathrm{N}+\mathrm{p} &\rightarrow { }^{15} \mathrm{O}+\gamma \\
{ }^{15} \mathrm{O} &\rightarrow { }^{15} \mathrm{N}+\mathrm{e}^{+}+\nu_{\mathrm{e}} \\
{ }^{15} \mathrm{N}+\mathrm{p} &\rightarrow { }^{12} \mathrm{C}+{ }^{4} \mathrm{He}+\gamma
\end{aligned}
$$

The overall reaction is:

$$
4 \mathrm{p} \rightarrow { }^{4} \mathrm{He}+2 \mathrm{e}^{+}+2 \nu_{\mathrm{e}}+4 \gamma+26.7 \mathrm{MeV}
$$

Thus, the fusion material actually consumed in the carbon-nitrogen reaction chain is hydrogen. The answer is (D).

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The mass of the $J/\psi$ particle is $3.097 \, \text{GeV}/c^{2}$, and it undergoes a complete symmetric decay $J/\psi \rightarrow e^{+} + e^{-}$. Given that the momentum of the $J/\psi$ is $100 \, \text{GeV}/c$ and it decays symmetrically, find the angle between the electron and the $J/\psi$ particle in the laboratory frame.
solution:
Let $\theta$ be the angle between the electron and the $J/\psi$ particle. Momentum conservation requires:

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{\mathrm{J}} &= 2p_{\mathrm{e}} \cos \theta \\
\left(\frac{E_{\mathrm{J}}}{2}\right)^{2} &- \left(\frac{p_{\mathrm{J}}}{2\cos \theta}\right)^{2} = E_{\mathrm{e}}^{2} - p_{\mathrm{e}}^{2} = m_{\mathrm{e}}^{2} \\
\cos \theta &= \frac{p_{\mathrm{J}}}{\sqrt{p_{\mathrm{J}}^{2} + m_{\mathrm{J}}^{2} - 4m_{\mathrm{e}}^{2}}} \\
&= \frac{100}{\sqrt{100^{2} + 3.097^{2} + 4 \times (0.511 \times 10^{-3})^{2}}} \\
&= 0.9995
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence:

$$
\theta = 1.77^{\circ}
$$

problem: When generating a beam of ions or electrons, the space charge within the beam generally creates a potential difference between the beam axis and the beam surface. A proton beam of $10 \ \mathrm{mA}$ and $50 \ \mathrm{keV}$ $(v = 3 \times 10^{6} \ \mathrm{m/s})$ moves along a vacuum tube, with the beam having a circular cross-section with a diameter of 1 cm. Assuming the current density is uniform across the diameter of the particle beam, calculate the potential difference between the beam axis and the beam surface.
solution:
Since $E = \frac{\mathrm{d}V}{\mathrm{d}r}$, the potential difference is given by

$$
\Delta V = \int_{0}^{R} E(r) \ \mathrm{d}r = \frac{I}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} v R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R} r \ \mathrm{d}r = \frac{I}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} v} = \frac{9 \times 10^{9} \times 10 \times 10^{-3}}{3 \times 10^{6}} = 30 \ \mathrm{V}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Assume a stationary \(\pi^{+}\) meson spontaneously decays as \(\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+} + \nu_{\mu}\). It is detected that the kinetic energy of \(\mu^{+}\) is 4.0 MeV. Given that the mass of \(\mu^{+}\) is \(106 \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}\), and the neutrino mass is 0, find the rest mass of the \(\pi^{+}\) meson.
solution:
Consider \(\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+} + \nu_{\mu}\).

Let the momentum of \(\mu^{+}\) be \(\mathbf{p}\), then the momentum of \(\nu_{\mu}\) is \(-\mathbf{p}\), and its energy is \(E_{\nu} = p\). The energy of \(\mu^{+}\) is given by \(E_{\mu} = T_{\mu} + m_{\mu} = 4 + 106 = 110 \mathrm{MeV}\).

From the following equation, we can determine the momentum \(p\) of \(\mu^{+}\):
\[ p = \sqrt{E_{\mu}^{2} - m_{\mu}^{2}} = 29.4 \, (\mathrm{MeV}/c) \]

Therefore, the mass of \(\pi^{+}\) is:
\[ m_{\pi} = E_{\mu} + p = E_{\mu} + \sqrt{E_{\mu}^{2} - m_{\mu}^{2}} = 139.4 \left(\mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}\right) \]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Consider the non-leptonic weak decays of hyperons $\Sigma^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \mathrm{n}$, $\Sigma^{-} \rightarrow \pi^{-} \mathrm{n}$, and $\Sigma^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{0} \mathrm{p}$, which satisfy the $\Delta S=1$ condition and obey the $\Delta I=\frac{1}{2}$ rule. Determine the amplitude ratio $y$, where $y=\frac{A\left(\Sigma^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \mathrm{n}\right)-A\left(\Sigma^{-} \rightarrow \pi^{-} \mathrm{n}\right)}{A\left(\Sigma^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{0} \mathrm{p}\right)}$.
solution:
For the non-leptonic decay of hyperons with $\Delta I=\frac{1}{2}$, introduce a "pseudo-particle" with $\left(I=\frac{1}{2}, I_{3}=\frac{1}{2}\right)$. In the isospin coupling representation, the hyperon and pseudo-particle couple together, and using the orthogonality of isospin wave functions, we determine the transition amplitude $A$. The coupling of the hyperon and pseudo-particle is:

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\Sigma^{-} \mathrm{a}\right\rangle=\left|1,-1, \frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=\left|\frac{3}{2},-\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle \\
& \left|\Sigma^{+} \mathrm{a}\right\rangle=\left|1,1, \frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left|\frac{3}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle+\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\left|\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle 
\end{aligned}
\]

Similarly, the wave function of the final state in the isospin representation is written as:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\pi^{+} \mathrm{n}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left|\frac{3}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle+\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\left|\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle \\
& \left|\pi^{-} \mathrm{n}\right\rangle=\left|\frac{3}{2},-\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle \\
& \left|\pi^{0} \mathrm{p}\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\left|\frac{3}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}\left|\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right\rangle 
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus, we can derive that:
\[ A_{3}\left(\Sigma^{-} \rightarrow \pi^{-} \mathrm{n}\right)=M_{3/2} \quad \text{where } M_{3/2}=\left\langle\frac{3}{2}\right| H_{\omega}\left|\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle \]

\[ A_{4}\left(\Sigma^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{0} \mathrm{p}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}\left(M_{3/2}-M_{1/2}\right) \]

\[ A_{5}\left(\Sigma^{+} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \mathrm{n}\right)=\frac{1}{3}\left(M_{3/2}+2 M_{1/2}\right) \]

We obtain the value of $y$:

\[ y=\frac{A_{5}-A_{3}}{A_{4}}=\frac{M_{3/2}+2 M_{1/2}-3 M_{3/2}}{\sqrt{2}\left(M_{3/2}-M_{1/2}\right)}=-\sqrt{2} \]

problem: A neutral meson is produced when a proton strikes a thin target. Each meson decays into two $\gamma$ photons. subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Using two accelerators, a neutral intermediate vector boson \( Z^0 \) is produced through the reaction \( \mathrm{e}^{+} + \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{Z}^{0} \). The mass of \( Z^0 \) is \( M = 91.187 \, \mathrm{GeV} \). What are the energy and velocity of the \( Z^0 \) produced in the laboratory frame? Assume that a positron (\(\mathrm{e}^{+}\)) collides with a stationary electron (\(\mathrm{e}^{-}\)).
solution:
In the center of mass frame, the total momentum of \(\mathrm{e}^{+}\) and \(\mathrm{e}^{-}\) is zero, and the total energy is \(2 E^{*}\), where \(E^{*}\) is the energy of either \(\mathrm{e}^{+}\) or \(\mathrm{e}^{-}\). Therefore, the square of the invariant mass is given by
\[
S = (E_{\mathrm{e}^{+}} + m_{\mathrm{e}})^2 - p_{\mathrm{e}}^2 = 2(E^{*})^2
\]
Thus,
\[
E^{*} = \frac{\sqrt{2 m_{e} E_{e^{+}} + 2 m_{e}^{2}}}{2} \approx \sqrt{\frac{m_{e} E_{\mathrm{e}^{+}}}{2}} = \frac{M_{Z}}{2}
\]
Hence, the relativistic factor in the center of mass frame is
\[
\gamma_{0} = \frac{E^{*}}{m_{\mathrm{e}}} = \sqrt{\frac{E_{\mathrm{e}^{+}}}{2 m_{\mathrm{e}}} + \frac{1}{2}} \approx \frac{M_{Z}}{2 m_{\mathrm{e}}}
\]
This is also the relativistic factor of the \( Z^0 \) produced in the center of mass frame. Thus, the total energy of \( Z^0 \) is
\[
E = \gamma_{0} M_{Z} \approx \frac{M_{Z}^2}{2 m_{\mathrm{e}}} \approx E_{\mathrm{e}^{+}}
\]
The velocity of \( Z^0 \) is
\[
\beta c = \left(1 - \frac{1}{\gamma_{0}^{2}}\right)^{1/2} c \approx \left[1 - \left(\frac{2 m_{\mathrm{e}}}{M_{Z}}\right)^{2}\right]^{1/2} c \approx \left(1 - \frac{2 m_{\mathrm{e}}^{2}}{M_{Z}^{2}}\right) c \approx c
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Calculate the relative cross section for the production of hadrons in positron-electron collisions:
\[ 
R = \frac{\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{h})}{\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-})} 
\]

(2) Above the threshold for charm quark production, but below the threshold for b quark production.
solution:
Quantum electrodynamics gives the cross section for the production of fermion pairs in positron-electron collisions as
\[ 
\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{f}_{i} \overline{\mathrm{f}}_{i}) = \frac{4 \pi \alpha^{2}}{3 s} Q_{i}^{2} 
\]
where \( s \) is the square of the total energy in the center of mass system, \(\alpha\) is the fine-structure constant, and \(Q_{i}\) is the charge of the fermion (in units of \(e\)). Fermions can be leptons or quarks, and for quarks, they must also fragment into hadrons. For the production of a muon pair,
\[ 
\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-}) = \frac{4 \pi \alpha^{2}}{3 s} 
\]
For the production of a quark-antiquark pair, we must consider the contribution of the color degree of freedom, thus
\[ 
\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{q}_{i} \overline{\mathrm{q}}_{i} \rightarrow \mathrm{h}) = 3 \cdot \frac{4 \pi \alpha^{2}}{3 s} Q_{i}^{2} = \frac{4 \pi \alpha^{2}}{s} Q_{i}^{2} 
\]
where \( h \) denotes the hadrons from quark fragmentation, and the factor of 3 accounts for the color degrees of freedom of the quark. Thus, we obtain
\[ 
R = \frac{\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{h})}{\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-})} = \sum_{i} \frac{\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{q}_{i} \overline{\mathrm{q}}_{i} \rightarrow \mathrm{h})}{\sigma(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-})} = 3 \sum_{i} Q_{i}^{2} 
\]
The summation includes all quarks that can be produced. At this energy, we can produce quark pairs including the charm quark, thus allowing for the production of \(u\), \(d\), \(s\), and \(c\) quarks. The value of \(R\) is
\[ 
R = 3 \sum_{i} Q_{i}^{2} = 3 \times \left(\frac{4}{9} + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{4}{9}\right) = \frac{10}{3} \approx 3.33 
\]

problem:
Consider conducting an experiment to measure the "single creation" reaction:

$$
a + N \rightarrow \mu^{+} + \mu^{-} + \text{other particles}
$$

In the reaction equation, $a$ can be $p, \pi^{+}$, or $\pi^{-}$. $N$ is a target composed of a nucleus with equal numbers of protons and neutrons. How can the quark composition of $\pi^{+}$ be determined from the experimental data?
solution: The calculated values $\frac{\mathrm{d} \sigma_{\pi^{+} N}(s, m)}{\mathrm{d} m} : \frac{\mathrm{d} \sigma_{\pi^{-} N}(s, m)}{\mathrm{d} m} = 1 : 4$ agree with the experimental data, indicating that the quark compositions of the mesons, $\pi^{+}(u \bar{d})$ and $\pi^{-}(\overline{u} d)$, are correct.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The $\eta^{0}$ particle is produced via an S-wave in the reaction $\pi^{-} + \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \eta^{0} + \mathrm{n}$. The rest mass of $\eta^{0}$ is 548.8 MeV. Describe an experimental measurement method to determine the parity, isospin, and charge of the $\eta^{0}$ particle.
solution:
The experiment can be arranged as follows: (1) a $\pi^{-}$ beam with variable momentum; (2) a hydrogen target; (3) a detector system with good spatial and energy resolution for $\gamma$ and charged particles. At this moment, the parameters for motion in the center of mass are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \beta_{\mathrm{c}} = \frac{p_{\pi}}{m_{\mathrm{p}} + E_{\pi}} = \frac{688}{702 + 938} = 0.420 \\
& \gamma_{\mathrm{c}} = 1.10 \\
& p_{\pi}^{*} = \gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(p_{\pi} - \beta_{\mathrm{c}}E_{\pi}) \approx 433 \text{ MeV} \\
& \lambda = 1/p_{\pi}^{*} = 0.45 \times 10^{-13} \text{ cm}
\end{aligned}
$$

The radius of the proton is $r \approx 0.5 \times 10^{-13} \text{ cm}$. At this point, the S-wave in the $\pi^{-} \mathrm{p}$ system plays the main role. Here, the invariant mass of the $2\gamma, 2\gamma$ in the final state is peaked at 548.8 MeV. The detection of $6\gamma$ events, wherein there are 3 pairs of $\gamma$ with invariant mass $m_{\pi^{0}}$, and the invariant mass of $6\gamma$ being 548.8 MeV, confirms the occurrence of the following reaction. Additionally, $\pi^{+} \pi^{-} \pi^{0}$ events can also be measured.

$$
\pi^{-}+p \rightarrow n+\eta^{0} \rightarrow 2 \gamma, 3 \pi^{0}, \pi^{+} \pi^{-} \pi^{0}
$$

If the reaction $\pi^{-} + \mathrm{p} \rightarrow \mathrm{p} + \eta^{-}$ were to occur, the decay of $\eta^{-}$ would be $\eta^{-} \rightarrow \pi^{+} \pi^{-} \pi^{-}$. Experimentally, no $\pi^{+} \pi^{-} \pi^{-}$ events were found, implying that $\eta^{-}$ production does not occur.

Based on the above experimental results, the parity, isospin, and charge of $\eta^{0}$ can be determined.

Parity: From the aforementioned decay branching ratios, it is determined that $\eta^{0}$ undergoes electromagnetic decay. It can decay into $3\pi^{0}$ with a very low probability of decaying into $2\pi$. $P(\eta^{0}) = P^3(\pi) \cdot (-1)^{l + l^{\prime}}$, where $l$ and $l^{\prime}$ are the orbital angular momentum of the two $\pi$ and the relative orbital angular momentum of the third $\pi$ relative to the other two $\pi$. $J(\eta^{0}) = J(\pi) = 0$, with total angular momentum conservation requiring the vectors of orbital angular momentum $l^{\prime}$ and $l$ to be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction, thus $(-1)^{l + l^{\prime}} = +1. P(\eta^{0}) = P_{3}(\pi) = -1$.

Isospin: Since $\eta^{-}$ was not observed, $\eta^{0}$ is considered to be an isospin singlet, $I(\eta^{0}) = 0$.  
Charge: Based on charge conservation, $Q(\eta^{0}) = 0$.

In summary, the parameters of $\eta^{0}$ are $m(\eta^{0}) = 548.8 \text{ MeV}, I(\eta^{0}) = 0, Q(\eta^{0}) = 0$. Like the $\pi$ and $\mathrm{K}$ mesons, it is a pseudoscalar meson, but it is an isospin singlet.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
(1) Explain which of the following four reactions can produce a pure neutral \( K \) beam, that is not contaminated by the presence of its antiparticle.

\[
\pi^{-} p \rightarrow\left(\Lambda^{0} \text{ or } \mathrm{K}^{0}\right)\left(\mathrm{K}^{0} \text{ or } \bar{K}^{0}\right)
\]
solution:
(1) The following reaction can yield a pure \(\mathrm{K}^{0}\) beam:

\[
\pi^{-}+\mathrm{p} \rightarrow \Lambda^{0}+\mathrm{K}^{0}
\]

This process involves strong interaction and satisfies various conservation laws, including \(\Delta s=0, \Delta I_{3}=0\). The reaction cannot produce \(\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\) because it would violate the conservation of \(I_{3}\). Therefore, a pure \(\mathrm{K}^{0}\) beam can be obtained.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Describe the parity of the $\pi^{0}$ meson and discuss in detail the method of determining its parity through the polarization plane of its decay.
solution:
The parity of $\pi^{0}$ is determined through the polarization plane from its decay into $2 \gamma$. Given $J(\pi^{0})=0$, the final state of the two photons is symmetric under exchange. The forms of the decay amplitude for the $2 \gamma$ decay include:

(1) $A \varepsilon_{1} \cdot \varepsilon_{2}$, corresponding to $p(\pi^{0})=+1$

(2) $B k \cdot\left(\varepsilon_{1} \times \varepsilon_{2}\right)$, corresponding to $p(\pi^{0})=-1$

Measurements have shown that the plane of the electron pairs is primarily orthogonal, indicating that the form of the $2 \gamma$ decay amplitude of $\pi^{0}$ is as shown in (2), meaning the parity of $\pi^{0}$ is negative.

problem: It is suggested to use the collision of antiprotons ($\overline{\mathrm{p}}$) stored in a ring with hydrogen gas injected perpendicularly into the ring, specifically $\mathrm{p} \overline{\mathrm{p}}$ annihilation, to study narrow hadronic resonant states in the laboratory. By varying the momentum of the $\overline{\mathrm{p}}$ beam in the storage ring, the dependence of the cross-section on the center-of-mass energy can be studied. Suppose this method can result in a hadron state with a mass of 3 GeV and a width of 100 keV. What beam momentum is required to produce this resonance?
solution:
In the laboratory, the speed of the gas is very low, and the proton ($\mathrm{p}$) is approximately stationary. Near the threshold energy, the invariant mass squared is 
$$
S = \left(E_{\mathrm{p}} + m_{\mathrm{p}}\right)^{2} - p_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} = 2 m_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} + 2 m_{\mathrm{p}} E_{\mathrm{p}} = M^{2}
$$
Using $E_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} = m_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} + p_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}, M = 3 \mathrm{GeV}$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\mathrm{p}} & = \frac{M^{2} - 2 m_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{2 m_{\mathrm{p}}} = \frac{3^{2} - 2 \times 0.938^{2}}{2 \times 0.938} = 3.86 \, \mathrm{GeV} \\
p_{\mathrm{p}} & = \sqrt{E_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} - m_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} \approx 3.74 \, \mathrm{GeV} / c
\end{aligned}
$$

problem: What are the spin and parity of the $\mathrm{K} \pi \pi$ final state? In an $\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-}$ collision with a center-of-mass energy of $E=4.03 \mathrm{GeV}$, a $\mathrm{D}^{+}$ is produced and decays into $\mathrm{K}^{-} \pi^{+} \pi^{+}$, and the Dalitz plot shows that the decay is uniform.
solution:
Based on the uniform Dalitz plot, the $\mathrm{K} \pi \pi$ system has $J=0$, meaning that the total angular momentum of the three-particle system is zero, and the $\mathrm{D}^{+}$ particle's spin is zero. Let the orbital angular momentum of the two $\pi$ particles be $l$, and the orbital angular momentum of the $\mathrm{K}$ relative to the two $\pi$ particles be $l^{\prime}$. Both $\mathrm{K}$ and $\pi$ are mesons with spin zero. Given that $J=l+l^{\prime}=0$, it follows that $l=-l^{\prime}$ and $|l|=|l^{\prime}|$. Therefore, we have:
$$
P(\mathrm{K} \pi \pi)=(-1)^{l+l^{\prime}} P^2(\pi) P(\mathrm{K})=(-1)^{3}=-1
$$

problem: Consider the "neutrino oscillation" under perturbative interactions, assuming the rest mass of the neutrino $M_{0} = 20 \mathrm{eV}$. Given that the flight distance of the neutrino is 2000 m, its energy is 100 GeV, and the experimental sensitivity reaches a 1% variation, find the minimum measurable value of $\hbar \omega$ and analyze its relationship with $M_{0}$.
solution:
To simplify the problem, consider only the oscillation between two types of neutrinos, and assume the maximum mixing angle $\theta = 45^{\circ}$. Given in problem 12.47 is

$$
P(\nu \rightarrow \nu, \mathrm{t})=1-\sin ^{2} 2 \theta \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{E_{1}-E_{2}}{2} t\right)=1-\sin ^{2}\left[1.27\left(\frac{l}{E} \Delta m^{2}\right)\right]
$$

where the unit of $l$ is meters, $E$ is in $\mathrm{MeV}$, and the unit of $\Delta m^{2}$ is $\mathrm{eV}^{2}$. From the problem statement, the precision for measuring the oscillation of neutrinos to other states is 0.01, i.e.

$$
1-P(\nu \rightarrow \nu, \mathrm{t})=\sin ^{2}\left[1.27\left(\frac{l}{E} \Delta m^{2}\right)\right] \geqslant 0.01
$$

Thus, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sin \left[1.27\left(\frac{l}{E} \Delta m^{2}\right)\right] \geqslant 0.1 \\
\Delta m^{2} \geqslant \frac{E}{1.27 l} \sin ^{-1}(0.1) \approx \frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{1.27 \times 2000} \times 0.1 \approx 3.94\left(\mathrm{eV}^{2}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Since

$$
\Delta m^{2}=\left(M_{0}+\hbar \omega_{1}\right)^{2}-M_{0}^{2} \approx 2 M_{0} \hbar \omega_{1}
$$

we need

$$
\hbar \omega_{1} \geqslant \frac{\Delta m^{2}}{2 M_{0}}=\frac{3.94}{2 \times 20} \approx 0.1(\mathrm{eV})
$$

The minimum measurable value of $\hbar \omega_{1}$ is $0.1 \mathrm{eV}$. When $M_{0} \gg \hbar \omega_{1}$, the minimum measurable value of $\hbar \omega_{1}$ is inversely proportional to $M_{0}$.

problem:
Due to the experimental observation of narrow, long-lived states \( J/\psi, \psi^{\prime} \), a new charm quantum number is introduced. Additionally, states of large mass \((\gamma, \gamma^{\prime}, \cdots)\) with mass \(\sim 10 \mathrm{GeV}\) have been observed. Experimentally, these states are discovered through their decay into lepton pairs. Thus, another new quantum number \(b\) (beauty) is introduced.

(3) Based on the colored quark model, estimate the relative total cross section for hadron production above the energy region exceeding the threshold for producing b quarks:

\[
R = \frac{\sigma(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow h)}{\sigma(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-})}
\]
solution:
(3) After a new quark is produced, its contribution to the \(R\) value is given by

\[
R = \frac{\sigma(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow Q \overline{Q})}{\sigma(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-})} = 3 Q^{2}
\]

where \(Q\) is the charge of this new quark. The factor of 3 accounts for the contribution of the three colors. If the total energy in the center-of-mass system is greater than the threshold to produce b quarks, quarks \(u, d, s, c\), and b can all be produced, so we have

\[
R = 3 \sum_{i} Q_{i}^{2} = 3\left[3 \times\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2} + 2 \times \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{2}\right] = \frac{11}{3}
\]

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c}

Meson Name & Mass (MeV) & Spin & Parity & C-Parity & Isospin $I$ & $I_{3}$ & $G$ \\

problem:
The relationship among the decay constant $\lambda$, half-life $T_{1/2}$, and mean life $\tau$ is:
(A) $\tau = \frac{0.693}{\lambda} = 0.693 T_{1/2}$
(B) $T_{1/2} = \frac{0.693}{\lambda} = 0.693 \tau$
(C) $\lambda = \frac{0.693}{\tau} = 0.693 T_{1/2}$
(D) $\lambda = 0.693 \tau = \frac{1}{T_{1/2}}$
solution: According to the law of nuclear decay, $N = N_{0} e^{-\lambda t}$, we have $t = (1/\lambda) \ln(N_{0}/N)$. The half-life is the time for the decay to reach half of the original amount: $T_{1/2} = (\ln 2) / \lambda = 0.693 / \lambda$. The mean life is $\tau = 1 / \lambda = T_{1/2} / 0.693$. Therefore, we obtain $T_{1/2} = 0.693 / \lambda = 0.693 \tau$. The answer is (B).

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A particle with a mass of $M=3 \, \text{GeV}/c^{2}$ and a momentum of $p=4 \, \text{GeV}/c$ moves along the $x$-axis and decays into two photons. In the particle's rest frame, the angular distribution of the photons is isotropic, i.e., $\frac{\mathrm{d} W}{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta^{*}}=\frac{1}{2}$. Find the maximum and minimum values of the momentum of the photons in the $x$ direction in the laboratory frame.
solution:
In the rest frame of the particle, the conservation of momentum and energy requires

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{1}^{*} + E_{2}^{*} = M, \quad \boldsymbol{p}_{1}^{*} + \boldsymbol{p}_{2}^{*} = 0, \quad p_{1}^{*} = p_{2}^{*} = p, \\
& E_{1}^{*} = E_{2}^{*} = E^{*} = \frac{M}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the energy of the photons is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{*} = \frac{M}{2} = \frac{3}{2} = 1.5 \, \text{GeV}, \\
p^{*} = E^{*} = 1.5 \, \text{GeV/c}.
\end{aligned}
$$

In the laboratory frame, for the decaying particle $\gamma \beta = \frac{p}{M} = \frac{4}{3}$

$$
\gamma = \sqrt{(\gamma \beta)^{2} + 1} = \frac{5}{3}, \quad \beta = \frac{\gamma \beta}{\gamma} = 0.8
$$

The Lorentz transformation provides the $x$ component of the photon momentum in the laboratory frame

$$
p_{x} = \gamma (p^{*} \cos \theta^{*} + \beta E^{*}) = \gamma p^{*} (\cos \theta^{*} + \beta),
$$

where $p^{*}$ and $\theta^{*}$ are the photon's momentum and its angle with the $x$-axis, respectively.

When $\theta^{*} = 0$, the momentum is at its maximum

$$
(p_{x})_{\text{max}} = \gamma (p^{*} + \beta E^{*}) = \frac{5}{3} \times 1.5(1 + 0.8) = 4.5 \, \text{GeV/c}.
$$

When $\theta^{*} = 180^{\circ}$, the momentum is at its minimum

$$
(p_{x})_{\text{min}} = \gamma (-p^{*} + \beta E^{*}) = \frac{5}{3} \times 1.5(-1 + 0.8) = -0.5 \, \text{GeV/c}.
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Describe the spin of the $\pi^{+}$ meson and discuss in detail the experimental method used to determine it.
solution:
The spin of the $\pi^{+}$ meson is determined by studying the reversible reaction: $\mathrm{pp} \rightarrow \mathrm{~d} \pi^{+}$. By applying the principle of detailed balance, we have:

$$  
\frac{\mathrm{d} \sigma}{\mathrm{~d} \Omega}\left(\mathrm{pp} \rightarrow \mathrm{~d} \pi^{+}\right)=\frac{\mathrm{d} \sigma}{\mathrm{~d} \Omega}\left(\mathrm{~d} \pi^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{pp}\right) \times 2 \frac{p_{\pi}^{2}\left(2 J_{\pi}+1\right)\left(2 J_{\mathrm{d}}+1\right)}{p_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}\left(2 J_{\mathrm{p}}+1\right)^{2}}  
$$

where $p_{\pi}$ and $p_{\mathrm{p}}$ are the momenta of $\pi$ and p in the center-of-mass system, respectively. By experimentally measuring different reaction cross sections and the momenta of the incident particles, and knowing $J_{\mathrm{d}}$ and $J_{\mathrm{p}}$, the experimental data indicates:

$$  
2 J_{\pi}+1=1.00 \pm 0.01  
$$

Therefore, the spin of $\pi^{+}$ is zero.

problem: In the same experiment, on the invariant mass spectrum of the $\mathrm{K}^{-} \pi^{+}$ system, at a location almost identical to the mass of $\mathrm{D}^{+}$, there exists another particle $\mathrm{D}^{0}$. What is the $J^{\mathrm{P}}$ of the $\mathrm{K} \pi$ state?
solution:
For the $\mathrm{K} \pi$ system, we have:
$$
P(\mathrm{K} \pi)=(-1)^{l} P(\pi) P(\mathrm{K})=(-1)^{l}
$$
with $J^{\mathrm{P}}=0^{+}, 1^{-}, 2^{+}, \cdots$. If it is known that $J(\mathrm{D})=0$, then we have $l=0$ and $P(\mathrm{K} \pi)=0^{+}$.

problem: The isotope $\mathrm{H}^{3}$ is an element that undergoes $\beta$ decay, with a half-life of 12.5 years. A sample rich in hydrogen gas contains 0.1 grams of tritium, releasing 21 calories of heat per hour. Calculate the average energy of the $\beta$ particle emitted during the $\beta$ decay.
solution:
The decay constant of tritium is

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lambda=\frac{\ln 2}{T_{1 / 2}}=\frac{\ln 2}{12.5 \times 365 \times 24}=6.33 \times 10^{-6}(\text{per hour}) \\
\frac{\mathrm{d} N}{\mathrm{~d} t}=\lambda N=\frac{0.1 \times 6.023 \times 10^{23}}{3} \times 6.33 \times 10^{-6}=1.27 \times 10^{17}(\text{per hour})
\end{gathered}
$$

The average energy of the $\beta$ particles is

$$
\bar{E}=\frac{21 \times 4.18}{1.27 \times 10^{17}}=6.91 \times 10^{-16}(\mathrm{~J})=4.3(\mathrm{keV})
$$

problem: Consider a beam of hydrogen molecules with a kinetic energy of 1 eV in an excited state moving along the $z$-axis. It is measured that the kinetic energy of the dissociated hydrogen atoms moving perpendicular to the $z$-axis is 0.8 eV. solution:
When one of the dissociated hydrogen atoms moves perpendicular to the $z$-axis, the momentum of the other dissociated hydrogen atom is $\boldsymbol{p}_{2}$. According to the conservation of momentum, $\boldsymbol{p}_{0}=\boldsymbol{p}_{1}+\boldsymbol{p}_{2}$. Therefore,

$$
p_{2}=\sqrt{p_{0}^{2}+p_{1}^{2}}=7.23 \times 10^{4}(\mathrm{eV} / c)
$$

The corresponding kinetic energy is

$$
E_{2}=\frac{p_{2}^{2}}{2 m(\mathrm{H})}=2.80 \mathrm{(eV)}
$$

problem: Give an example of an octet state and list all the particles in the octet along with their common quantum numbers.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: It is known that secondary cosmic rays interact with nitrogen in the atmosphere to continually produce \(^{14} \mathrm{C}\), keeping its deposition in atmospheric \(\mathrm{CO}_{2}\) approximately stable. When an organic organism dies, the proportion of \(^{14} \mathrm{C}\) in its body is the same as in the atmosphere, but decreases over time due to radioactive decay. This is the basis of radiocarbon dating. Assuming the ratio of \(^{14} \mathrm{C}\) to \(^{12} \mathrm{C}\) in the atmosphere is \(10^{-12}\), and the \(\beta\) decay half-life of \(^{14} \mathrm{C}\) is 5730 years. Using radiocarbon dating to determine the age of a carbon sample, assuming the age of the sample is 5000 years, and a detector with a detection efficiency of \(100\%\) records for 1 hour without any background. How many grams of carbon sample are necessary to achieve a measurement precision (standard deviation) of \(\pm 50\) years?
solution:
The decay law of \(^{14} \mathrm{C}\) is

\[
N = N_{0} e^{-\lambda t}
\]

The counting rate is

\[
\begin{aligned}
A & = -\frac{\mathrm{d} N}{\mathrm{d} t} = \lambda N_{0} e^{-\lambda t} = \lambda N \\
\mathrm{d} A & = \lambda^{2} N_{0} e^{-\lambda t} = \lambda A_{0} \mathrm{d} t \\
\frac{\Delta A}{A} & = \lambda \Delta t
\end{aligned}
\]

Since \(\Delta t = 50, \lambda = \frac{\ln 2}{T_{1/2}} = \frac{\ln 2}{5730} \approx 1.21 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{y}^{-1}\), and because the counting rate \(A\) follows a Poisson distribution, we have

\[
\frac{\Delta A}{A} = \frac{\sqrt{A}}{A} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{A}} = 50\lambda
\]

Then,

\[
A = \left(\frac{1}{50 \lambda}\right)^{2} = \left(\frac{1}{50 \times 1.21 \times 10^{-4}}\right)^{2} \approx 2.73 \times 10^{4} (\mathrm{h}^{-1})
\]

Assume the mass of the carbon sample is \(m\) grams, then \(A = \lambda N = \frac{\lambda m N_{\mathrm{A}}}{12} \times 10^{-12} \times \exp(-5000 \lambda)\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
m & = \frac{12 A \times 10^{12}}{\lambda N_{\mathrm{A}}} \times \exp(5000 \lambda) \\
& \approx \frac{12 \times 2.73 \times 10^{4} \times 365 \times 24}{1.21 \times 10^{-4} \times 6.023 \times 10^{23}} \times \exp(5000 \times 1.21 \times 10^{-4}) \times 10^{12} \\
& \approx 72.1 (\mathrm{g})
\end{aligned}
\]

problem: In the Fermilab, pions produced by a proton beam with a momentum of 400 GeV have the most probable momentum when the velocity of the $\pi$ meson is equal to the velocity of the proton. What is the momentum of the $\pi$ meson? Given $m_{\pi}=0.14 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$ and $m_{\mathrm{P}}=0.938 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$.
solution:
Since the $\pi$ meson and proton have the same speed, $\beta$, and therefore the same $\beta \gamma$, and since $p_{\pi}=m_{\pi} \beta \gamma, p_{\mathrm{p}}=m_{\mathrm{p}} \beta \gamma$, we have

\[
p_{\pi}=\frac{m_{\pi}}{m_{\mathrm{P}}} p_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{0.14}{0.938} \times 400=59.7 \ (\mathrm{GeV} / c)
\]

problem: A beam of $\mu^{-}$ is absorbed by matter, enabling the $\mu^{-}$ to be captured by an atom and enter a bound orbit around the nucleus. Determine whether this process can occur.
solution: The $\mu^{-}$ can be captured by an atom in an orbit outside the nucleus, forming an exotic $\mu$ atom. This process can indeed occur. Therefore, the answer is "yes".

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The hyperfine splitting of the spectral term $2 \mathrm{D}_{\frac{3}{2}}$ of a ${}^{209} \mathrm{Bi}$ atom has 4 components, and the ratio of the intervals between adjacent components is $4: 5: 6$. Determine the spin quantum number of this nucleus.
solution:
The number of components for the given spectral term is determined by $2 J+1$, thus we have $2 J+1=4$, $J=\frac{3}{2}$. The interaction energy between the electronic magnetic moment and the nuclear magnetic moment is $\Delta E=-\mu_{\mathrm{J}} \cdot \boldsymbol{B}_{\mathrm{N}}=c_{1}(\boldsymbol{J} \cdot \boldsymbol{I})$, where $c_{1}$ is a proportionality constant.

Based on $F=J+I$, we have:

$$
J \cdot I = \frac{1}{2}[F(F+1) - I(I+1) - J(J+1)] h^{2}
$$

Note: Since all sub-energy levels have the same $I$ and $J$, the interval between adjacent sub-energy levels is:

$$
\Delta E_{J+1} - \Delta E_{J} = c_{1}(F+1)
$$

This indicates that the ratio of the intervals between adjacent sub-energy levels characterized by quantum numbers $F, F+1, \cdots$ is $F+1: F+2: \cdots$.

According to the problem, $4: 5: 6 = (F+1):(F+2):(F+3)$, from which we find $F=3$. This means the 4 energy levels corresponding to the hyperfine splitting relate to the total atomic angular momentum quantum numbers $F=3, 4, 5$, and 6. Using $F=I+J$, we then have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3 = I + \frac{3}{2} \\
& I = \frac{9}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The rest lifetime of a muon is $10^{-6} \, \text{s}$, and its rest mass is approximately $100 \, \text{MeV}/\mathrm{c}^2$. If it is produced in the upper atmosphere (above $10^{4} \, \text{m}$), how much energy must the muon have to reach the ground?
solution:
Let the energy of the muon be $E = \gamma m$, and $\tau_{0}$ be the average lifetime of the muon in its rest frame. The average lifetime in the laboratory frame is $\tau = \gamma \tau_{0}$, thus the path length is $l = \gamma \beta \tau_{0} c$. Therefore,

$$
E = \frac{l m}{\beta \tau_{0} c} \approx \frac{l m}{\tau_{0} c} = \frac{10^{4} \times 0.1}{10^{-6} \times 3 \times 10^{8}} = 3.3 \, \text{GeV}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Explain which partial wave (s, p, d, ...) of the deuteron is effective in the excited state of the compound nucleus in the reaction $\mathrm{Li}^{6}+\mathrm{d} \rightarrow \alpha+\alpha$.
solution:
Considering the initial state $\mathrm{d}+{ }^{6} \mathrm{Li}$ system, it must be $J_{\mathrm{i}}=2$, because $J_{\mathrm{i}}=J_{\mathrm{d}}+J_{\mathrm{Li}}+l_{\mathrm{i}}=1+1+l_{\mathrm{i}}$.

$$
1+1=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
2
\end{array} \quad \text{The possible values of } l_{\mathrm{i}} \text{ are: } 0,1,2,3 \text{ and } 4 \right.
$$

Both the deuteron and ${ }^{6} \mathrm{Li}$ have even parity, so $l_{i}$ must be an even number. Moreover, since the angular distribution of the final state is not isotropic, $l_{\mathrm{i}}$ cannot be zero. The possible values of $l_{\mathrm{i}}$ are 2 and 4. Hence, the d-wave plays a major role.

problem:
In a spin echo experiment, a liquid sample containing protons (such as glycerol) is placed in a stable but spatially non-uniform magnetic field, with a magnetic field strength of several thousand Gauss. A strong pulse of a few Gauss (lasting a few microseconds) radio frequency field is applied perpendicular to the stable magnetic field direction, thus immediately producing a radio frequency signal on the coil surrounding the sample. However, unless special measures are taken to ensure the spatial uniformity of the magnetic field is very good so that the signal can last longer, the signal will disappear in less than a millisecond.  
(2) What are the requirements for the spatial uniformity of the stable field?
solution:
Let the maximum difference of \(\boldsymbol{B}_{0}\) within the sample be \((\Delta B)_{\mathrm{m}}\). It can be proven that the decay time is \(\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{p}}(\Delta B)_{\mathrm{m}}}\). It is required that \(\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{p}}(\Delta B)_{\mathrm{m}}}>\tau\), where \(\tau\) is the time interval between the two pulses, thus the requirement is:

$$
(\Delta B)_{\mathrm{m}}<\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{p}} \tau}
$$

Take the stable field \(\boldsymbol{B}_{0}\) along the \(z\)-axis direction.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Given $N=N_{0} \exp (-\mu t)$, find the relationship between the error in $N$ and the error in the thickness $t$ of the aluminum plate.
solution:
Since $N=N_{0} \exp(-\mu t)$, the relationship between the error in $N$ and the error in $t$ is connected through the error propagation relation, $\frac{\mathrm{d}N}{N}=-\mu \mathrm{d}t$.

$$
\frac{\Delta N}{N}=\mu \Delta t
$$

Thus,

$$
\frac{\Delta N}{N}=\mu t\left(\frac{\Delta t}{t}\right)
$$

problem: Write down the decay equation of the muon ($\mu^{-}$) and identify all the particles involved.
solution:
The decay equation for $\mu^{-}$ is

$$
\mu^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{-}+\tilde{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}+\nu_{\mu}
$$

where $\mathrm{e}^{-}$ is the electron, $\tilde{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}$ is the electron antineutrino, and $\nu_{\mu}$ is the muon neutrino.
