subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
\(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) is an intermediate vector boson mediating weak interactions, and it was first discovered at CERN's \(\mathrm{p} \overline{\mathrm{p}}\) collider. The \(\mathrm{p} \overline{\mathrm{p}}\) collision process is as follows:

\[
\mathrm{p} + \overline{\mathrm{p}} \rightarrow \mathrm{W}^{+} + \mathrm{X}
\]

\[
\mathrm{W}^{+} \rightarrow \mathrm{e}^{+} + \nu
\]

The mass of the intermediate vector boson \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) is \(M_{\mathrm{W}}=82\) GeV. In the quark model, the fundamental production process involves the collision of a \(u\) quark from the proton and a \(\overline{\mathrm{d}}\) quark from the antiproton. The cross-section for this process is

\[
\sigma^{\mathrm{ud} \rightarrow \mathrm{W} \rightarrow \mathrm{ev}}(\hat{s})=16 \pi \frac{N_{\mathrm{W}}}{N_{i}} \frac{\Gamma_{\mathrm{ud}} \Gamma_{\mathrm{ev}}}{\left(\hat{s}-M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2}\right)^{2}+M_{\mathrm{W}}^{2} \Gamma^{2}}
\]

where \(N_{\mathrm{W}}\) and \(N_{i}\) are the multiplicative factors for the final state \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) and the initial state \(u + \overline{\mathrm{d}}\).

(1) What are the magnitudes of \(N_{\mathrm{W}}\) and \(N_{i}\)?
solution: The multiplicative factors largely stem from contributions of spin and color. When calculating the decay width \(\Gamma_{\mathrm{ud}}\) for \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\) decaying into a \(u\) quark and \(\overline{\mathrm{d}}\) quark, one needs to sum over all possible final states while averaging over the spin of the decaying \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\). Conversely, here, we are concerned with two quarks colliding to produce \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\). Therefore, the multiplicity factor should average over the spin and color degrees of freedom of the initial state \(u\) and \(\overline{\mathrm{d}}\) quarks. The spin contribution is \(2^{2}\), and the color contribution is \(3^{2}\), giving \(N_{i}=2^{2} \times 3^{2}=36\). For the final state \(\mathrm{W}^{+}\), summing over its spin gives \(N_{\mathrm{W}}=2 J+1=3\).

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: The linear accelerator built at SLAC in the United States can produce electron and positron beams for collision experiments, with each electron having an energy of 50 GeV in the laboratory frame. Each beam contains \(10^{10}\) particles and can be considered as a uniformly charged cylinder with a radius of \(1 \, \mu \mathrm{m}\) and a length of 2 mm in the laboratory. For an observer in the laboratory and an observer moving with the particles, how much time is needed for the two beams to pass through each other?
solution:
For an observer in the laboratory frame, the velocity of each particle is

\[
\beta=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{1}{10^{5}}\right)^{2}} \approx 1
\]

The time required for the two particle beams to pass through each other is

\[
t=\frac{L}{v}=\frac{2 \times 10^{-3}}{1 \times 3 \times 10^{8}}=6.67 \times 10^{-12} \, \mathrm{s}
\]

For an observer moving with the particles, the speed of the oncoming particles is

\[
\beta^{\prime}=\frac{2 \beta}{1+\beta^{2}} \approx \beta \approx 1
\]

The time required to pass through each other is

\[
t^{\prime}=\frac{L+L_{0}}{v}=\frac{200+1 \times 10^{-8}}{3 \times 10^{8}}=6.67 \times 10^{-7} \, \mathrm{s}
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
In the high-energy neutrino detector experiment at Fermilab, the neutrino beam is obtained from the decay of monoenergetic $\pi^{+}$ (or $\text{K}^{+}$): $\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \nu_{\mu}$. The rest masses of $\pi^{+}$ and $\mu^{+}$ are $140\, \text{MeV}/c^{2}$ and $106\, \text{MeV}/c^{2}$ respectively.

(3) Find the angle $\theta$ that yields an energy value for the neutrino that is half of the maximum energy.
solution:
When $\theta = \theta^{*} = 0$, the neutrino energy is maximum, which is:

$$
\left(E_{\nu}\right)_{\max }=\gamma E_{\nu}^{*}(1+\beta)
$$

For $E_{\nu}=\frac{1}{2}\left(E_{\nu}\right)_{\text{max}}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma E_{\nu}^{*}\left(1+\beta \cos \theta_{1 / 2}^{*}\right) & =\frac{1}{2} \gamma E_{\nu}^{*}(1+\beta) \\
\cos \theta_{1 / 2}^{*} & =\frac{\beta-1}{2 \beta} \\
\sin \theta_{1 / 2}^{*} & =\sqrt{1-\cos ^{2} \theta_{1 / 2}^{*}}=\frac{\sqrt{3 \beta^{2}+2 \beta-1}}{2 \beta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the Lorentz transformation to the neutrino:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{\nu} \sin \theta_{1 / 2}=p_{\nu}^{*} \sin \theta_{1 / 2}^{*} \\
& p_{\nu} \cos \theta_{1 / 2}=\gamma\left(p_{\nu}^{*} \cos \theta_{1 / 2}^{*}+\beta E_{\nu}^{*}\right)=\gamma E_{\nu}^{*}\left(\cos \theta_{1 / 2}^{*}+\beta\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\beta \approx 1$, we have

$$
\tan \theta_{1 / 2}=\frac{\sin \theta_{1 / 2}}{\cos \theta_{1 / 2}}=\frac{\sqrt{3 \beta^{2}+2 \beta-1}}{\gamma\left(\beta-1+2 \beta^{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{\gamma} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \beta-1} \sqrt{\frac{3 \beta-1}{\beta+1}} \approx \frac{1}{\gamma}
$$

Therefore, the angle corresponding to half the maximum value is

$$
\theta_{1 / 2} \approx \frac{1}{\gamma}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Assume there is a particle $\mu$ with charge $e$, spin of $\frac{1}{2}$, and rest mass $M$. It undergoes spontaneous decay into an electron with mass $m$ and a photon. In its rest system, the average lifetime is $\tau$. Suppose the energy per unit volume and frequency interval of incoming photons is $U(\omega) \mathrm{d} \omega$. What is the probability for an electron to generate this particle per unit time?
solution:
Time reversal invariance requires

$$
\sum_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}\left|S_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}(\mu \rightarrow \mathrm{e}+\gamma)\right|^{2} = \sum_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}\left|S_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}(\mathrm{e}+\gamma \rightarrow \mu)\right|^{2}
$$

The lifetime of the $\mu$ particle is

$$
\frac{1}{\tau} = \frac{2 \pi}{\left(2 s_{\mu}+1\right)} \sum_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}\left|S_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}(\mu \rightarrow \mathrm{e}+\gamma)\right|^{2} \frac{\mathrm{d} \Omega}{(2 \pi)^{3}} \frac{p^{2} \, \mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} E}
$$

where $p$ is the momentum of one of the final state particles. The total energy $E=M$, i.e., $E=p+\sqrt{p^{2}+m^{2}}$, substituted into the lifetime formula, gives

$$
\frac{1}{\tau} = \frac{1}{\pi\left(2 s_{\mu}+1\right)} \left(\frac{M^{2}-m^{2}}{2M}\right)^{2} \left(\frac{M^{2}+m^{2}}{2M^{2}}\right) \sum_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}\left|S_{s_{\mu}, s_{e}, \varepsilon}(\mu \rightarrow \mathrm{e}+\gamma)\right|^{2}
$$

In the rest system of the $\mu$ particle, the probability of generating an unpolarized $\mu$ particle for the inverse process is

$$
\Gamma_{0} = \frac{2 \pi}{2\left(2 s_{\mathrm{e}}+1\right)} \sum_{s_{\mu}, s_{\mathrm{e}}, \varepsilon}\left|S_{s_{\mu}, s_{\mathrm{e}}, \varepsilon}(\mathrm{e}+\gamma \rightarrow \mu)\right|^{2} \frac{\mathrm{d} N}{\mathrm{d} E}
$$

where $\frac{\mathrm{d} N}{\mathrm{d} E}$ is the initial state density in the center-of-mass system, given by

$$
\mathrm{d} N = \sqrt{(1-v)(1+v)}[U(\omega) \mathrm{d} \omega / \omega]
$$

Substituting into the calculation we obtain

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\mathrm{d} N}{\mathrm{d} E} = \frac{\left(M^{2}+m^{2}\right)}{2M^{2}} \cdot \frac{U\left(\omega_{0}\right)}{\omega_{0}} \\
\Gamma_{0} = 4 \pi^{2} \cdot \frac{\left(2 s_{\mu}+1\right)}{\left(2 s_{\mathrm{e}}+1\right)} \cdot \frac{M^{2}}{\left(M^{2}-m^{2}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{U\left(\omega_{0}\right)}{\omega_{0}} \frac{1}{\tau}
\end{gathered}
$$

This is the generation probability in the center-of-mass system. Converting to the laboratory system, we have

$$
\Gamma_{\mathrm{Lab}} = \frac{\Gamma_{0}}{\gamma} = \frac{8 \pi^{2}\left(2 s_{\mu}+1\right) M^{2} m}{\left(2 s_{\mathrm{e}}+1\right)\left(M^{2}-m^{2}\right)^{2}\left(M^{2}+m^{2}\right)} \cdot \frac{U\left(\omega_{0}\right)}{\omega_{0}} \frac{1}{\tau}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A rapidly moving magnetic monopole with a magnetic charge of $g$ is scattered by a nucleus with an electric charge of $Ze$. Calculate the classical non-relativistic differential cross-section for small angles.
solution:
In the rest frame of the nucleus, the electric field is given by

$$
\boldsymbol{E} = Ze \frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{r^{3}}
$$

The strength of the magnetic monopole is $g$, and the force it experiences is

$$
\boldsymbol{F} = g\left(\boldsymbol{B} - \frac{v}{c} \times \boldsymbol{E}\right)
$$

The force results in a change in momentum of the magnetic monopole

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{p}}{\mathrm{d}t} = -Ze g \frac{\boldsymbol{v} \times \boldsymbol{r}}{cr^{3}}
$$

For small angle scattering as depicted in Figure 3.34, let

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{v} = (v, 0, 0) \\
& \boldsymbol{r} = (vt, b, 0)
\end{aligned}
$$

The change in momentum can be expressed as the change in velocity, resulting in

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\mathrm{d}v_{z}}{\mathrm{d}t} = -\frac{Ze g}{mc} \frac{b v}{(b^{2} + v^{2} t^{2})^{3/2}} \\
\frac{\mathrm{d}v_{x}}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{\mathrm{d}v_{y}}{\mathrm{d}t} = 0
\end{gathered}
$$

Integrating the above expression, with $v_{z}(-\infty) = 0$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& v_{z}(t) = \frac{Ze g}{mc b}\left(1 + \frac{vt}{(b^{2} + v^{2} t^{2})^{1/2}}\right) \\
& v_{z}(\infty) = \frac{Ze g}{mc b}
\end{aligned}
$$

The scattering angle is

$$
\theta \approx \frac{v_{z}(\infty)}{v} = \frac{Ze g}{mc b v}
$$

This equation provides the relationship between the impact parameter $b$ and the scattering angle $\theta$. Let $f$ be the flux of the incident particles, and the conservation of particle number requires

$$
f \cdot 2\pi b \, \mathrm{d}b = -f \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} 2\pi \, \mathrm{d}\cos\theta
$$

Here, the left-hand side represents the number of incident particles per unit time within a ring of radius $b$ and thickness $\mathrm{d}b$, while the right-hand side is the scattering rate into the solid angle $\mathrm{d}\Omega = 2\pi \, \mathrm{d}\cos\theta$. The scattering cross-section is obtained as

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} = \frac{b}{\sin\theta}\left|\frac{\mathrm{d}b}{\mathrm{d}\theta}\right| \approx \frac{b}{\theta}\left|\frac{\mathrm{d}b}{\mathrm{d}\theta}\right| = \left(\frac{2Ze g}{mc v}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{\theta^{4}} = \left(\frac{g}{e}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{v}{c}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega}\right)_{0}
$$

where $\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega}\right)_{0}$ is the Rutherford scattering cross-section.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
The principle of "laser cooling" an atom is as follows: In a vacuum chamber, a highly collimated beam of \({ }^{23} \mathrm{Na}\) atoms (produced by evaporation at a high temperature of \(10^{3} \mathrm{~K}\)) is irradiated head-on by a high-intensity laser beam. The laser frequency \(
u\) is chosen so that sodium atoms with velocity \(v_{0}\) resonate and absorb the laser, transitioning to the first excited state with energy \(E\) and level width \(\Gamma\). The change in velocity is \(\Delta v_{1} = v_{1} - v_{0}\), and the atom then emits a photon and returns to the ground state, with the change in velocity during this process being \(\Delta v^{\prime} = v^{\prime}_{1} - v_{1}\). If we only consider the case \(\varphi = 0\), where the absorption and emission processes always proceed along a straight line, the total change in the atom's velocity reaches a certain amount \(\Delta v\), after which the atom no longer resonates with the laser of frequency \(
u\).

Given: \(E = 3.36 	imes 10^{-19} \mathrm{~J}\), \(\Gamma = 7.0 	imes 10^{-27} \mathrm{~J}\), \(m_{\mathrm{Na}} = 3.82 	imes 10^{-26} \mathrm{~kg}\), \(h = 6.62 	imes 10^{-34} \mathrm{~J} \cdot \mathrm{s}\). If the frequency \(
u\) is held constant, what is the maximum decrease in the atom's velocity \(\Delta v_{1}\)?
solution:
As the atom's velocity decreases, the frequency of light required for resonant absorption increases according to the following formula:

\[
\nu = \frac{E / h}{1+v_{0} / c}
\]

After maintaining \(\nu\) constant, as long as \(\Delta v\) satisfies the following equation, absorption can still occur at the lowest part of the energy level even when the velocity decreases to \(\left(v_{0}-\Delta v\right)\),

\[
h \nu = \frac{E-\Gamma / 2}{1+\left(v_{0}-\Delta v\right) / c} = \frac{E}{1+v_{0} / c}
\]

Thus,

\[
\Delta v = \frac{c \Gamma}{2 E}\left(1+\frac{v_{0}}{c}\right) = 3.12 \, \text{m/s}
\]

In fact, from the context of the problem, it can be determined that the \(\Delta v\) here should be half of the \(\Delta v_{0}\) sought in equation (2).

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Given that the wavelength of zinc's \( K_{\alpha} \) X-rays is 0.1434 nm, the K absorption edge of nickel is 0.1489 nm, and the mass absorption coefficient of nickel for zinc's \( K_{\alpha} \) X-rays is \( 325 \ \text{cm}^2 \cdot \text{g}^{-1} \). Determine how thick a nickel absorber is needed to reduce the intensity of zinc's \( K_{\alpha} \) X-rays to its original value of \( 1 \).
solution:
Consider the reduction of the intensity of zinc's \( K_{\alpha} \) X-rays to its original value of \( 1 \), which implies no additional absorption is required. Therefore, maintain the original formula in the final calculation and compare with the result for copper.

The absorption of zinc's \( K_{\alpha} \) X-rays by nickel follows the exponential decay law \( I = I_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-\mu_m^\prime \rho x} \). Using the formula directly confirms that no additional absorption is necessary:

\[
\frac{I}{I_{0}} = \mathrm{e}^{-\mu_{m}^{\prime} \rho x} = 1
\]

No calculations are needed because, under the current problem scenario, the use of an absorber is unnecessary.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
The nucleus is a bound state of neutrons and protons. The Hamiltonian in the center-of-mass frame has the following form:

$$
H=\frac{\boldsymbol{p}^{2}}{2 \mu}+V_{1}(r)+\sigma_{\mathrm{p}} \cdot \sigma_{\mathrm{n}} V_{2}(r)+\left[\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\mathrm{p}} \cdot \frac{\boldsymbol{x}}{r}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\mathrm{n}} \cdot \frac{\boldsymbol{x}}{r}\right)-\frac{1}{3}\left(\sigma_{\mathrm{p}} \cdot \sigma_{\mathrm{n}}\right)\right] V_{3}(r)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{n}}-\boldsymbol{x}_{\mathrm{p}}, r=|\boldsymbol{x}|$, $\sigma_{\mathrm{p}}$ and $\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{\mathrm{n}}$ are the Pauli matrices for the spins of the proton and neutron, $\mu$ is the reduced mass, and $\boldsymbol{p}$ is the momentum conjugate to $\boldsymbol{x}$. Assume that $V_{3}$ can be considered a perturbation. Prove that the zeroth-order (i.e., $V_{3}=0$) wave function (with angular momentum $J_{z}=+1$) has the form $\Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle$, where $|\alpha, \alpha\rangle$ is the spin state with $s_{\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{z}}}=s_{\mathrm{n}_{\mathrm{z}}}=\frac{1}{2}$. What differential equation does $\Psi_{0}(r)$ satisfy?
solution:
If $V_{3}=0$, the Hamiltonian is centrally symmetric. The central symmetric potential interaction between the proton and neutron can be described by an S state (i.e., $L=0$ state). Due to the presence of the perturbation $V_{3}$, the D state is mixed into the S state of the nucleus.

Considering the case of $V_{3}=0$, where $L=0, S=1, 2 S^{2}-3=2 \times 1 \times 2-3=1$, and $S_{z}=1$, so $J_{z}=+1$, the wave function has the form $\Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
H \Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle= & {\left[-\frac{\nabla^{2}}{2 \mu}+V_{1}(r)+\left(2 S^{2}-3\right) V_{2}(r)\right] \Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle } \\
= & {\left[-\frac{\nabla^{2}}{2 \mu}+V_{1}(r)+V_{2}(r)\right] \Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle } \\
= & E_{\mathrm{c}} \Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle \\
& {\left[-\frac{\nabla^{2}}{2 \mu}+V_{1}(r)+V_{2}(r)-E_{\mathrm{c}}\right] \Psi_{0}(r)|\alpha, \alpha\rangle=0 }
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{1}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} r}\left[r^{2} \Psi_{0}^{\prime}(r)\right]+\left[V_{1}(r)+V_{2}(r)-E_{\mathrm{c}}\right] \Psi_{0}(r)=0 \\
& -\frac{1}{2 \mu} \Psi_{0}^{\prime \prime}(r)-\frac{1}{\mu r} \Psi_{0}^{\prime}(r)+\left[V_{1}(r)+V_{2}(r)-E_{\mathrm{c}}\right] \Psi_{0}(r)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Assume that, corresponding to the electron and muon Dirac neutrinos, there are two types of neutrinos, $
u_{1}$ and $
u_{2}$, with masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ respectively, forming a mixed state:
$$
 egin{gathered}

u_{\mathrm{e}}=
u_{1} \cos 	heta+
u_{2} \sin 	heta \

u_{\mu}=-
u_{1} \sin 	heta+
u_{2} \cos 	heta
\end{gathered}
$$
Here, $	heta$ is called the mixing angle. The mass term of the Hamiltonian is given by
$$
H=m_{1}  ar{
u}_{1} 
u_{1}+m_{2}  ar{
u}_{2} 
u_{2}
$$

Assume that at time $t=0$, we have a pure electron neutrino $
u_{\mathrm{e}}$. What is the probability of finding a muon neutrino $
u_{\mu}$ at time $t$?
solution:
At time $t=0$, we have a pure electron neutrino $\nu_{\mathrm{e}}$, which is a mixed state of $\nu_{1}$ and $\nu_{2}$:
$$
\nu_{\mathrm{e}}=\nu_{1} \cos \theta+\nu_{2} \sin \theta
$$

At time $t$, the state $\psi_{\mathrm{e}}(t)$ of $\nu_{\mathrm{e}}$ evolves into:
$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{\mathrm{e}}(t) & =\nu_{1} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{1} t} \cos \theta+\nu_{2} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{2} t} \sin \theta \\
& =\left(\nu_{\mathrm{e}} \cos \theta-\nu_{\mu} \sin \theta\right) \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{1} t} \cos \theta+\left(\nu_{\mathrm{e}} \sin \theta+\nu_{\mu} \cos \theta\right) \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{2} t} \sin \theta \\
& =\left(\cos ^{2} \theta \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{1} t}+\sin ^{2} \theta \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{2} t}\right) \nu_{\mathrm{e}}+\sin \theta \cos \theta\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{2} t}-\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{1} t}\right) \nu_{\mu}
\end{aligned}
$$

At time $t$, the probability of finding the $\nu_{\mu}$ state is:
$$
\begin{aligned}
P\left(\nu_{\mathrm{e}} \rightarrow \nu_{\mu}, t\right) & =\left|\left\langle\nu_{\mu} \mid \psi_{\mathrm{e}}(t)\right\rangle\right|^{2}=\sin ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta\left|-\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{1} t}+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} E_{2} t}\right|^{2} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \sin ^{2}(2 \theta) \left[1-\cos \left(E_{1}-E_{2}\right) t\right]=\sin ^{2}(2 \theta) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{E_{1}-E_{2}}{2} t\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Suppose a muon decays into an electron and two distinguishable neutrinos. The decay rate of the muon, where the momentum of the decay electron is between \( p \) and \( p + \mathrm{d}p \), is given by:

\[ 
\mathrm{d} \Gamma = \frac{2 \pi}{\hbar} \left(\frac{g}{V}\right)^2 \frac{V p^2}{2 \pi^2} \frac{\mathrm{d}p \mathrm{d}n}{\hbar^3 \mathrm{d}W} 
\]

where \( g \) is the coupling constant, \( V \) is the normalization volume, \( p \) is the momentum of the emitted electron, and \( W \) is the total energy of the three emitted particles.  
Calculate the number of neutrino states per unit energy interval \(\mathrm{d} n / \mathrm{d} W\), and derive an expression for the electron momentum spectrum; (assuming the energy of the electron \(\approx pc\)).
solution:
The density of states for the final state can be expressed as

\[ 
\mathrm{d}n = \frac{V}{(2 \pi \hbar)^3} \mathrm{d}^3 p 
\]

To express this in terms of energy, let \(|\boldsymbol{p}_{v_1}| = \boldsymbol{p}_{v_1}, |\boldsymbol{p}_e| = \boldsymbol{p}_e, \cos \theta = \frac{\boldsymbol{p}_e \cdot \boldsymbol{p}_{v_1}}{\boldsymbol{p}_e \boldsymbol{p}_{v_1}}\). The conservation of momentum and energy requires

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{p}_e + \boldsymbol{p}_{v_1} + \boldsymbol{p}_{v_2} = 0 \\
& W = (|\boldsymbol{p}_e| + |\boldsymbol{p}_{v_1}| + |\boldsymbol{p}_{v_2}|) c
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus, we obtain

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathrm{d}n}{\mathrm{d}W} & = 2 \pi V \sin \theta \mathrm{d} \theta p_{v_1}^2 \frac{\mathrm{d}p_{v_1}}{\mathrm{d}W} \\
& = 2 \pi V \sin \theta \mathrm{d} \theta \frac{(Mc)^2}{8c}(Mc - 2p_e)^2 \left\{ \frac{2(Mc-p_e)(pc \cos \theta - p_e) + M^2 c^2}{(Mc - p_e + p_e \cos \theta)^4} \right\}
\end{aligned}
\]

where the total decay energy \(w = Mc^2\), and \(M\) is the mass of the muon. Integrating over \(\theta\) and substituting into the decay probability expression yields

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d}\Gamma & = \frac{2 \pi}{\hbar} g^2 \frac{p^2 \mathrm{d}p}{2 \pi^2 \hbar^3} \frac{1}{(2 \pi \hbar)^3} \frac{\pi}{6c}(3M^2 c^2 - 6Mcp + 2p^2) \\
& = A p^2 (3w^2 - 6wpc + 2p^2 c^2) \mathrm{d}p \quad A = \frac{g^2}{48 \pi^3 \hbar^7 c^3}
\end{aligned}
\]

This means the number of emitted electrons with momentum between \(p\) and \(\mathrm{d}p\) is proportional to \(p^2 (3w^2 - 6wpc + 2p^2 c^2)\), with the electron's maximum momentum being \(\frac{Mc}{2}\).

An alternative intuitive approach: \(n(W)\) is proportional to \(\int \mathrm{d}^3 p_{v_1}\), subject to the constraints

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{p}_e + \boldsymbol{p}_{v_1} + \boldsymbol{p}_{v_2} = 0 \\
& w = (|\boldsymbol{p}_e| + |\boldsymbol{p}_{v_1}| + |\boldsymbol{p}_{v_2}|) c
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus, \(n(W)\) is proportional to the volume of the ellipsoid in Figure 3.15, with the semi-major axis \(a = \frac{1}{2}(W - pc)\), and semi-minor axes \(b = c = \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{(W^2 - 2Wp_ec)}\), and the volume of the ellipsoid is

\[
V = \frac{4 \pi}{3} abc = \frac{\pi}{6}(W - p_ec)(W^2 - 2 W p_ec)
\]

Therefore, \(\frac{\mathrm{d}n}{\mathrm{d}W}\) is proportional to  

\[
<image 1>
\]

In Figure 3.15

\[
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}W}[(W - p_ec)(W^2 - 2 W p_ec)] = 3W^2 - 6Wp_ec + 2 p_e^2 c^2
\]

problem: A pair of positron and electron are produced in the plane perpendicular to the magnetic field in a cloud chamber, creating a track with a curvature radius of 3 cm. Given that the magnetic field strength is 0.11 T, calculate the magnitude of momentum for both the positron and electron.
solution:
Since \( e v B = \frac{m v^2}{\rho} = \frac{p v}{\rho} \), we have

\[
p c = e c B \rho = \frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 3 \times 10^{8}}{1.6 \times 10^{-13}} B \rho = 300 B \rho
\]

The magnitude of momentum for \( \mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \) is

\[
\begin{aligned}
p & = 300 B \rho = 300 \times 0.11 \times 0.03 \\
& = 0.99 \, \mathrm{MeV} / c
\end{aligned}
\]

problem:
The ground state of a sodium atom \((Z=11)\) is \(3s\). It is known that the wavenumber of its resonance line is \(1.6952 \times 10^{6} \ \mathrm{m}^{-1}\), the first line of the diffuse series has a wavenumber of \(1.2218 \times 10^{6} \ \mathrm{m}^{-1}\), the first line of the principal series has a wavenumber of \(5.4158 \times 10^{5} \ \mathrm{m}^{-1}\), and the series limit wavenumber of the sharp series is \(2.4492 \times 10^{6} \ \mathrm{m}^{-1}\).

(3) Calculate the effective nuclear charge on the atomic nucleus for the electrons in \(3s, 3p, 3d\) states, retaining two significant figures, and briefly explain the physical significance of this result.
solution:
(3) \(Z^{*}=\left(\frac{T n^{2}}{R}\right)^{1 / 2}=\left(\frac{T n^{2} h c}{R h c}\right)^{1 / 2}\). Using \(n=3, R h c=13.6 \ \mathrm{eV}, h c=1240 \ \mathrm{eV} \cdot \mathrm{nm}\), the effective charges for electrons in the \(3s, 3p, 3d\) states are calculated as follows:

\[
\begin{aligned}
& Z_{3s}^{*}=1.8, \quad Z_{3p}^{*}=1.4, \quad Z_{3d}^{*}=1.0 \\
& Z_{3s}^{*} > Z_{3p}^{*} > Z_{3d}^{*} \geqslant 1
\end{aligned}
\]

This indicates that valence electrons have a certain probability of penetrating the atomic core and approaching the nucleus. For states with the same \(n\) but different \(l\), the smaller the \(l\), the greater the probability of the electron appearing closer to the nucleus, resulting in a higher effective nuclear charge it experiences. When \(l\) is larger, the electron is further away from the nucleus and the \((Z-1)\) electrons, experiencing a more fully shielded nucleus, such as in the case of the 3d electron, leading to \(Z_{3d}^{*} \rightarrow 1\).

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: In the $e^{+} e^{-}$ collision experiment, experimental evidence for the existence of gluons was discovered. Quarks of various types, or flavors, are referred to as u (up) and d (down) quarks, etc. According to QCD theory, how many types of quarks are there for each flavor, and what are their charges? Does QCD theory have any restrictions on the number of quarks? Current experimental data indicate how many flavors of quarks actually exist. Provide the evidence for this. Does the weak interaction indicate the current number of quark flavors, or does it predict more? At various energy levels, how does the total cross-section for the reaction $e^{+}+e^{-} \rightarrow$ hadrons relate to the number of quark flavors?
solution:
According to QCD theory, each quark has three colors. The three colors of quarks of the same flavor have the same charge. Quarks are characterized by fractional charges. QCD theory weakly restricts the number of quark types (if the number of quarks exceeds 16, it would disrupt asymptotic freedom). The weak interaction also does not limit the flavors of quarks. However, cosmological observations require the number of neutrinos to be around $3 \sim 4$. From the measurement of the total decay width of the $Z^{0}$ boson, it is indicated that there are only three types of neutrinos. Based on the symmetry between leptons and quarks, quarks can have at most $6 \sim 8$ flavors. At different energy levels, the measured relative total cross-section for positron-electron collisions producing hadrons is

$$
R=\frac{\sigma\left(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow \text{hadrons}\right)}{\sigma\left(e^{+} e^{-} \rightarrow \mu^{+} \mu^{-}\right)}=\sum_{i} Q_{i}^{2}
$$

$Q_{i}$ is the charge of the $i$-th quark, and the factor of 3 is the contribution from the three colors. The summation $\sum$ is over all quarks that can be produced at that energy level.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
The following non-relativistic Hamiltonian can be used to describe a nucleon system:  
$$  
H_{2}=H_{1}-\sum_{i} \frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\left(2 z_{i}^{2}-x_{i}^{2}-y_{i}^{2}\right),  
$$  
In this expression, determine which quantum numbers are absolutely and approximately conserved, and identify the quantum numbers of the final occupied single-particle orbitals for $n=11, 13, 15$.
solution:
The absolutely conserved quantities for $H_{2}$ are the total energy $E$, the third component of the total angular momentum $\Omega$, and parity. When the deformation is large, the coupling $l \cdot \boldsymbol{s}$ can be ignored, and at this point, $l_{z}$ and $S_{z}$ are good quantum numbers, although they are asymptotic good quantum numbers. The basis of the wave function is $\left|N n_{3} l_{z} S_{z}\right\rangle$, where $n_{3}$ is the quantum number of the harmonic oscillator relating to linear vibration along the $Z$ axis. When the deformation is large, the quantum numbers $N, n_{3}$, and $l_{z}$ can uniquely determine the state of the particle. These quantum numbers are known as asymptotic quantum numbers. For $H_{2}$, it can also be rewritten as  
$$  
H_{2}=H_{1}-\sum_{i} \frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} r_{i}^{2}\left(3 \cos ^{2} \theta-1\right)  
$$  
which is the Hamiltonian for a deformed nucleus. At this point, the energy levels $1 \mathrm{p}_{3/2}, 1 \mathrm{~d}_{3/2}$, and $1 \mathrm{~d}_{5/2}$ split further:  
$$  
\begin{aligned}  
& 1 \mathrm{d}_{5/2} \text { splits into } \frac{1}{2}^{+}, \frac{3}{2}^{+}, \frac{5}{2}^{+}, \\  
& 1 \mathrm{d}_{3/2} \text { splits into } \frac{1}{2}^{+}, \frac{3}{2}^{+}, \\  
& 1 \mathrm{p}_{3/2} \text { splits into } \frac{1}{2}^{-}, \frac{3}{2}^{-}.  
\end{aligned}  
$$  
Assuming a deformation parameter $\varepsilon$, the order of level splitting depends on the deformation parameter. According to $\varepsilon=0.3$ (where $\varepsilon=0.3$ for the ${ }^{27} \mathrm{Al}$ nucleus), in the single-particle model of a deformed nucleus, the state occupied by the last nucleon is  
$$  
\begin{aligned}  
& n=11: \frac{3}{2}^{+} \left(1 \mathrm{~d}_{5/2} \text { of } \frac{3}{2}^{+}\right), \\  
& n=13: \frac{5}{2}^{+} \left(1 \mathrm{~d}_{5/2} \text { of } \frac{5}{2}^{+}\right), \\  
& n=15: \frac{1}{2}^{+} \left(2 \mathrm{~s}_{1/2}\right).  
\end{aligned}  
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: If photons with an energy of $80 \, \mathrm{keV}$ are used to irradiate barium, what is the range of kinetic energy of electrons ejected from the layers from the N shell to $n=\infty$? It is known that the K absorption edge of tungsten is $0.0178 \, \mathrm{nm}$, the average wavelength of the K$_{\alpha}$ line series is $0.0211 \, \mathrm{nm}$, and that of the K$_{\beta}$ line series is $0.0184 \, \mathrm{nm}$.
solution:
The kinetic energy of photoelectrons ejected from the N shell is

$$
E_{e_1} = E_{\gamma} - \left|E_4\right| = 80 - 0.4 = 79.6 \, \mathrm{keV}
$$

When $n$ is very large, the binding energy of the electron can be ignored, and the kinetic energy of the photoelectron is approximately

$$
E_e (n = \infty) = E_{\gamma} = 80 \, \mathrm{keV}
$$

Therefore, the range of kinetic energy of photoelectrons ejected from layers beyond the N shell is $79.6 \sim 80 \, \mathrm{keV}$.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
A negatively charged $\pi^{-}$ meson (pseudoscalar particle: zero spin, odd parity) is initially bound to the lowest energy state Coulomb wave function in a deuteron nucleus. It is captured by the deuteron (the bound state of a proton and a neutron, ${ }^{3} \mathrm{~S}_{1}$) and transforms into a pair of neutrons:

$$
\pi^{-}+\mathrm{d} \rightarrow \mathrm{n}+\mathrm{n}
$$

What is the probability that the spin orientations of both neutrons are opposite to the spin of the deuteron nucleus?
solution:
The initial state's $J=1$, with the deuteron's spin orientation as the $z$ direction. The spin orientations of both neutrons are opposite to the deuteron's spin, i.e., $S_{f_{z}}=-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}=-1, J_{z}=l_{z}+S_{z}=l_{z}-1$. For the p state, $l_{f}=1, l_{z}=0,\pm1$. We have

$$
\left|\left\langle 1, l_{z}-1 \mid 1,1\right\rangle\right|^{2}=0
$$

This means it cannot combine with the p state $\left(l_{f_{z}}=1, 0, -1\right)$ to achieve a state with $J_{z}=+1$. Therefore, the probability of detecting both neutrons with spin orientations opposite to the deuteron's spin is 0.

problem: Consider the scattering of a neutrino off a free, massless quark. To simplify the problem, we will only discuss strangeness-conserving reactions, i.e., only the reactions between $u$ and $d$ quarks are considered. For the reaction $\nu_{\mu} d \rightarrow \mu^{-} u$, calculate its cross-section, neglecting $m_{\mu}, m_{d}$, and $m_{u}$.
solution:
For $\nu_{\mu} d \rightarrow \mu^{-} u$, when neglecting $m_{\mu}, m_{d}$ and $m_{u}$, the scattering differential cross-section in the center-of-mass system is

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} \sigma}{\mathrm{~d} \Omega}=\frac{1}{64 \pi^{2} S}|M|^{2}
$$

where $S$ is the invariant mass, for the above reaction, we have

$$
S=(k+p)^{2}=2 k \cdot p
$$

$$
|M|^{2}=\frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[k^{\prime} \gamma^{\mu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right) k \gamma^{\nu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right)\right] \times \frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[p^{\prime} \gamma_{\mu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right) p \gamma_{\nu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right)\right] \cos^{2} \theta_{c}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Tr}\left[k^{\prime} \gamma^{\mu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right) k \gamma^{\nu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right)\right] = 8\left(k^{\prime\mu} k^{\nu}+k^{\prime\nu} k^{\mu}+\frac{q^{2}}{2} g^{\mu\nu}-i \varepsilon^{\mu\nu\gamma\delta} k^{\prime}_{\gamma} k_{\delta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, we obtain

$$
\operatorname{Tr}\left[p^{\prime} \gamma_{\mu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right) p \gamma_{\nu}\left(1-\gamma_{5}\right)\right]=8\left(p^{\prime}_{\mu} p_{\nu}+p^{\prime}_{\nu} p_{\mu}+\frac{q^{2}}{2} g_{\mu\nu}-i \varepsilon_{\mu\nu\beta\alpha} p^{\prime\beta} p^{\alpha}\right)
$$

where $q^{2}=-\left(k-k^{\prime}\right)^{2}=-2 k \cdot k^{\prime}$ is the square of the momentum transfer. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |M|^{2}=64 G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} (k \cdot p)^{2} \cos^{2} \theta_{\mathrm{c}}=16 G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} S^{2} \cos^{2} \theta_{c} \\
& \frac{\mathrm{~d} \sigma}{\mathrm{~d} \Omega}\left(\nu \mathrm{~d} \rightarrow \mu^{-} \mathrm{u}\right)_{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{16 G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} S^{2} \cos^{2} \theta_{\mathrm{c}}}{64 \pi^{2} S}=\frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} S}{4 \pi^{2}} \cos^{2} \theta_{\mathrm{c}}
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: In a laboratory, a 200 GeV $\pi^{+}$ meson decays to produce a $\mu^{+}$ with a mass of $105.7 \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}$. Calculate the maximum angle at which the muon ($\mu^{+}$) is moving concerning the direction of the $\pi^{+}$ in the laboratory.
solution:
Perform a Lorentz transformation on the $\mu$, where the relativistic factor $\gamma = 1433$ for the $\pi^{+}$ is also the Lorentz factor for $\Sigma^{*}$, with $\beta \approx 1$.

$$
\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta^{*}}{\gamma\left(\cos \theta^{*} + \frac{1}{\beta_{\mu}^{*}}\right)} = \frac{\sin \theta^{*}}{\gamma\left(\cos \theta^{*} + \frac{1}{\beta_{\mu}^{*}}\right)}
$$

where $\beta_{\mu}^{*} = \frac{p_{\mu}^{*}}{E_{\mu}^{*}}$.

To find the maximum value of $\theta$, set $\frac{d(\tan \theta)}{d \theta} = 0$, resulting in

$$
\cos \theta^{*} = -\beta_{\mu}^{*}, \sin \theta^{*} = \sqrt{1 - (\beta_{\mu}^{*})^2} = \frac{1}{\gamma_{\mu}^{*}}
$$

Thus,

$$
(\tan \theta)_{\max} = \frac{1}{\gamma \gamma_{\mu}^{*}\left(-\beta_{\mu}^{*} + \frac{1}{\beta_{\mu}^{*}}\right)} = \frac{\beta_{\mu}^{*}}{\gamma \gamma_{\mu}^{*}\left(1 - (\beta_{\mu}^{*})^2\right)} = \frac{\gamma_{\mu}^{*} \beta_{\mu}^{*}}{\gamma} = \frac{\sqrt{\gamma_{\mu}^{*2} - 1}}{\gamma}
$$

Since $\gamma_{\mu}^{*} = \frac{E_{\mu}^{*}}{m_{\mu}} = \frac{109.8}{105.7} = 1.039, \gamma = 1433$, we get

$$
\theta_{\max} = \operatorname{arctan} (\tan \theta)_{\max} \approx \frac{\sqrt{\gamma_{\nu}^{*2} - 1}}{\gamma} = 1.97 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~rad} = 0.011^{\circ}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Alpha particles are used to bombard ${ }_{4}^{9} \mathrm{Be}$, producing ${ }_{6}^{12} \mathrm{C}$ and emitting another particle. If the energy released by this reaction is 5.7 MeV, find the change in mass of the system after the reaction compared to before the reaction. ($1 \mathrm{MeV} = 1.602 \times 10^{-6}$ erg, $1 \mathrm{u} = 1.66057 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}, \sin 56^{\circ} = 0.832$).
solution:
The kinetic energy of the system of particles before the reaction is

$$
T_{0}=\frac{1}{2} m_{\alpha} v_{\alpha}^{2}=7.5 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{erg}=4.66 (\mathrm{MeV})
$$

The kinetic energy of the system of particles after the reaction is

$$
\begin{gathered}
T=\frac{1}{2} m_{\mathrm{c}} v_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{\mathrm{n}} v_{\mathrm{n}}^{2}=10.61 \mathrm{MeV} \\
\Delta T=T-T_{0}=5.95 \mathrm{MeV}
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\Delta m=5.95 \times 1.783 \times 10^{-27}=1.061 \times 10^{-26} (\mathrm{~g})
$$

The increase in energy after the reaction indicates that the mass of the system of particles has decreased by $1.061 \times 10^{-26} \mathrm{~g}$.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Assume there are three types of neutrinos: $
u_{e}$, $
u_{\mu}$, and $
u_{	au}$. Suppose all neutrinos have the same non-zero rest mass $M_{0}$, and there exists a perturbative interaction with perturbation matrix elements $h\omega$ for each pair of neutrinos. At time $t=0$, a neutrino $
u_{e}$ is produced at rest. The task is to calculate the probability of this neutrino transitioning into the other two states $
u_{\mu}$ and $
u_{	au}$ as a function of time.
solution:
Let the wave function of the neutrino be

$$
|\Psi\rangle = a_{1}(t)\left|\nu_{\mathrm{e}}\right\rangle + a_{2}(t)\left|\nu_{\mu}\right\rangle + a_{3}(t)\left|\nu_{\mathrm{\tau}}\right\rangle
$$

The perturbation matrix is given by

$$
H^{\prime} = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & \hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & 0 & \hbar \omega_{1} \\
\hbar \omega_{1} & \hbar \omega_{1} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

According to perturbation theory, we have the equation

$$
\mathrm{i} \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2} \\
a_{3}
\end{array}\right) = \hbar \omega_{1} \left(\begin{array}{lll}
0 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 1 \\
1 & 1 & 0
\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{l}
a_{1} \\
a_{2} \\
a_{3}
\end{array}\right)
$$

This yields the differential equations

\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathrm{i} \dot{a}_{1} = \omega_{1}\left(a_{2}+a_{3}\right) \tag{1} \\
\mathrm{i} \dot{a}_{2} = \omega_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{3}\right) \\
\mathrm{i} \dot{a}_{3} = \omega_{1}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}\right)
\end{array}\right.
\]

From equations (2) and (3), we obtain

$$
\mathrm{i}\left(\dot{a}_{3} - \dot{a}_{2}\right) = -\omega_{1}\left(a_{3} - a_{2}\right)
$$

This can be rewritten as

$$
a_{3}(t) - a_{2}(t) = A \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}
$$

Given: $a_{2}(0) = a_{3}(0) = 0$, we have $A=0$, which implies $a_{2} = a_{3}$. The system equations can thus be transformed into

\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{a}_{1} = 2 \omega_{1} a_{2} \tag{4} \\
\mathrm{i} \dot{a}_{2} = \omega_{1}\left(a_{1} + a_{2}\right)
\end{array}\right.
\]

Using the differential equation

$$
\ddot{a}_{2} + i \omega_{1} \dot{a}_{2} + 2 \omega_{1}^{2} a_{2} = 0
$$

Solving this equation yields

$$
a_{2} = A_{1} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t} + A_{2} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}
$$

Since at $t=0$, $a_{2}(0) = 0$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
A_{1} + A_{2} = 0 \\
a_{2} = A_{1}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t} - \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Substituting into equation (4), we get

$$
\dot{a}_{1} = -\mathrm{i} 2 \omega_{1} A_{1}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t} - \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}\right)
$$

Thus,

$$
a_{1} = -2 A_{1} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t} - A_{1} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}
$$

Since $a_{1}(0) = 1$, we have $A_{1} = -1 / 3$. Therefore,

$$
a_{2} = a_{3} = \frac{1}{3}\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} 2 \omega_{1} t} - \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}\right)
$$

At time $t$, the probability of finding the neutrino in the state $\left|\nu_{\mu}\right\rangle$ or $\left|\nu_{\tau}\right\rangle$ is

$$
P\left(\left|\nu_{\mu}\right\rangle\right) = P\left(\left|\nu_{\tau}\right\rangle\right) = \left|a_{2}\right|^{2} = \frac{1}{9}\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} 2 \omega_{1} t} - \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} 2 \omega_{1} t} - \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \omega_{1} t}\right) = \frac{2}{9}\left[1 - \cos \left(3 \omega_{1} t\right)\right]
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: In a laboratory, a 200 GeV $\pi^{+}$ meson decays to produce neutrinos. Given that the mass of the $\pi^{+}$ is $139.6 \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}$ and the neutrino mass is 0, calculate the maximum and minimum momentum that the neutrino can have.
solution:
The energy of the neutrino is given by

$$
E_{\nu}^{*} = m_{\pi} - E_{\mu}^{*} = \frac{m_{\pi}^{2} - m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}} = 29.8 \mathrm{MeV}
$$

Its momentum is $29.8 \mathrm{MeV}/c$. From the Lorentz transformation,

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{\nu} & = E_{\nu} = \gamma \left(E_{\nu}^{*} + \beta p_{\nu}^{*} \cos \theta^{*}\right) = \gamma p_{\nu}^{*}\left(1 + \beta \cos \theta^{*}\right) \\
(p_{\nu})_{\max} & = \gamma p_{\nu}^{*}(1 + \beta) = 1433 \times 29.8 \times (1 + 1) = 85.4 \mathrm{~GeV} \\
(p_{\nu})_{\min} & = \gamma p_{\nu}^{*}(1 - \beta) = \left[\sqrt{(\gamma \beta)^2 + 1} - \gamma \beta\right] p_{\nu}^{*} \approx \frac{p_{\nu}^{*}}{2 \gamma \beta} = \frac{m_{\pi} p_{\nu}^{*}}{2 p_{\pi}} \\
& = \frac{139.6 \times 29.8}{2 \times 200 \times 10^3} = 1.04 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~MeV}/c
\end{aligned}
$$

problem: Consider the reaction $\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{H} \rightarrow \mathrm{f} \overline{\mathrm{f}}$, where $m_{\mathrm{H}}=50 \mathrm{MeV}$. The $\mathrm{f} \overline{\mathrm{f}}$ is primarily a pair of b quarks and their antiquarks ($m_{\mathrm{b}}=5 \mathrm{GeV}$). Find the cross section at resonance. If a positron-electron collider's luminosity is $2 \times 10^{31} \mathrm{~cm}^{-2} \cdot \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$, how many Higgs events can be produced in a year?
solution:
According to the Breit-Wigner resonance formula, the cross section for the reaction process $\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{H} \rightarrow \mathrm{f} \overline{\mathrm{f}}$ is given by

$$
\sigma=\left(\frac{4 \pi s}{k^{2}}\right)\left[\frac{2 J+1}{\left(2 s_{\mathrm{a}}+1\right)\left(2 s_{\mathrm{b}}+1\right)}\right] \frac{\Gamma_{\mathrm{f} \overline{\mathrm{f}}} \Gamma_{\mathrm{e}^{+} e^{-}}}{\left(s-m_{\mathrm{H}}^{2}\right)^{2}+m_{\mathrm{H}}^{2} \Gamma^{2}}
$$

where $\Gamma$ is the total decay width of the resonance, $s_{\mathrm{a}}$ and $s_{\mathrm{b}}$ are the spins of the incoming particles, J is the spin of the resonance, $s$ is the square of the center-of-mass energy, and $k$ is the momentum of the fermions. Let $s_{\mathrm{a}}=s_{\mathrm{b}}=1 / 2, J=0$. At resonance, $s=4 k^{2}=m_{\mathrm{H}}^{2}$, resulting in

$$
\sigma=\left(\frac{4 \pi}{m_{\mathrm{H}}^{2}}\right) \frac{\Gamma_{\mathrm{f} \overline{\mathrm{f}}} \Gamma_{\mathrm{e}^{+} e^{-}}}{\Gamma^{2}}
$$

For a scalar Higgs particle predominantly decaying into a $\mathrm{b} \overline{\mathrm{b}}$ quark pair, we have $\Gamma=3 \Gamma_{\mathrm{b}}$, where the factor 3 accounts for the contribution of quark colors. Thus, the reaction cross section is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma & =\left(\frac{4 \pi}{m_{\mathrm{H}}^{2}}\right) \frac{\Gamma_{\mathrm{e}^{+} e^{-}}}{\Gamma_{\mathrm{b}}}=\left(\frac{4 \pi}{m_{\mathrm{H}}^{2}}\right)\left(\frac{m_{\mathrm{e}}}{m_{\mathrm{b}}}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3} = \frac{4 \pi}{3\left(50 \times 10^{3}\right)^{2}}\left(\frac{0.5}{5 \times 10^{3}}\right)^{2} \\
& =\frac{4 \pi}{3 \times 5^{2}} \times 10^{-16}=1.68 \times 10^{-17}\left(\mathrm{MeV}^{-2}\right)=6.72 \times 10^{-39}\left(\mathrm{~cm}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting the luminosity $2 \times 10^{31} \mathrm{~cm}^{-2} \cdot \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$, we find the number of scalar Higgs particle events generated in one year is

$$
N=\sigma L t=6.72 \times 10^{-39} \times 2 \times 10^{31} \times 3.16 \times 10^{7} \approx 4.3
$$

This indicates that the number of scalar Higgs particle events is too few, making the detection of scalar Higgs particles very challenging.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A "thermalized" particle has a 50% probability of decaying while traveling 4 meters. Calculate the particle's intrinsic half-life in its rest frame, and determine the distance it would have traveled in the laboratory before "thermalization" when 50% of it has decayed.
solution:
The definition of half-life \( T \) is given by

\[
\exp\left(-\frac{t}{T}\right) = \exp\left(-\frac{l}{\beta c T}\right) = \frac{1}{2},
\]

or

\[
T = \frac{l}{\beta c \ln 2}, \quad T = \gamma T_{0}.
\]

Therefore,

\[
T_{0} = \frac{T}{\gamma} = \frac{l_{2}}{\beta_{2} \gamma_{2} c \ln 2} = \frac{4}{0.6 \times 1.25 \times 3 \times 10^{8} \times 0.693} \approx 2.6 \times 10^{-8} \, \mathrm{s}.
\]

The parameters of the particle before "thermalization" are

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \beta_{1} = \frac{p_{1}}{E_{1} + m_{0}} = \frac{0.81}{0.68 + 0.14} \approx 0.99, \\
& \gamma_{1} = \frac{E_{1} + m_{0}}{m_{0}} = \frac{0.68 + 0.14}{0.14} \approx 5.9.
\end{aligned}
\]

The distance traveled by the particle in the laboratory before 50% decay when "thermalized" is

\[
l_{1} = T_{0} \cdot \beta_{1} \gamma_{1} c \ln 2 = 2.6 \times 10^{-8} \times 0.693 \times 0.99 \times 5.9 \times 3 \times 10^{8} \approx 32 \, \mathrm{m}.
\]

problem:
Ignoring conservation, the neutral \( \mathrm{K}^{0} \) meson \( \left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle \) and \( \left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle \) can be expressed in terms of the states \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle \) and \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle \):

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right), \\
& \left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle-\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right).
\end{aligned}
\]

The states \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle \) and \( \left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle \) have lifetimes \( \tau_{\mathrm{L}}=\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{L}}} \) and \( \tau_{\mathrm{S}}=\frac{1}{\gamma_{\mathrm{S}}} \) respectively, and different rest masses, i.e., \( m_{\mathrm{L}} c^{2} \neq m_{\mathrm{S}} c^{2} \). Assuming a meson is in the state \( |\Psi(t=0)\rangle=\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle \) at \( t=0 \), find the probability \( \bar{P}_{0}(t) \) of the system being in the \( \left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle \) state at time \( t \).
solution:
At \( t=0 \), the state is

\[
\Psi(0)=\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right)
\]

At time \( t \), the state is

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \Psi(t)=\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} H t} \Psi(0)=\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} H t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2}\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{L}}\right\rangle+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2}\left|\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{S}}\right\rangle\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left\{\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle+\left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle\right)+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle-\left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle\right)\right\} \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2}+\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2}\right)\left|\mathrm{K}^{0}\right\rangle+\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{L}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t / 2}-\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} m_{\mathrm{S}} t-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t / 2}\right)\left|\overline{\mathrm{K}}^{0}\right\rangle\right]
\end{aligned}
\]

Here, \( \bar{P}_{0}(t) \) is given by

\[
\bar{P}_{0}(t)=\frac{1}{4}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\gamma_{\mathrm{L}} t}+\mathrm{e}^{-\gamma_{\mathrm{S}} t}-2 \mathrm{e}^{-\left(\gamma_{\mathrm{L}}+\gamma_{\mathrm{S}}\right) t / 2} \cos \left((m_{\mathrm{L}}-m_{\mathrm{S}}) t\right)\right]
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Using the classical magnetic dipole interaction, calculate the hyperfine interaction Hamiltonian of positronium and determine the energy difference between the singlet and triplet states.
solution:
Following the conventions of writing the Hamiltonian, we express the classical Hamiltonian for the magnetic dipole-dipole interaction of positronium $\left(\mathrm{e}^{+} \mathrm{e}^{-}\right)$, and then represent quantum mechanical operators using discrete $\boldsymbol{r}$ and magnetic moments. The classical magnetic field at a distance $\boldsymbol{r}$ from the positron's magnetic moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{e}^{+}$ is given by:

\[
B(\boldsymbol{r})=\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{r}^{3}}\left(\frac{3\left(\boldsymbol{r} \cdot \boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{+}\right) \boldsymbol{r}}{\boldsymbol{r}^{2}}-\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{+}\right)+\frac{8 \pi}{3} \boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{+}\boldsymbol{\delta}^{3}(\boldsymbol{r})
\]

The interaction energy with the electron's magnetic moment $\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{-}$ is $-\left[\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{-}\cdot B(\boldsymbol{r})\right]$, where

\[
\mu_{\mathrm{e}}^{+}=+\frac{g_{\mathrm{s}} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}}{\hbar} \boldsymbol{S}_{1} \quad \text{and} \quad \boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{-}=-\frac{g_{\mathrm{s}} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}}{\hbar} \boldsymbol{S}_{2}
\]

Here, $\boldsymbol{S}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{S}_{2}$ are the spins of the electron and positron respectively, and $\boldsymbol{r}$ is a vector operator. Substituting $\mu_{\mathrm{e}}^{+}\boldsymbol{\mu}_{\mathrm{e}}^{-}$ into the energy expression, we obtain the hyperfine interaction Hamiltonian:

\[
H=\frac{g_{\mathrm{s}}^{2} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}}{\hbar^{2} r^{3}}\left[\frac{3\left(\boldsymbol{r} \cdot \boldsymbol{S}_{1}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{r} \cdot \boldsymbol{S}_{2}\right)}{r^{2}}-\left(\boldsymbol{S}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{S}_{2}\right)\right]+\frac{8 \pi}{3}\left(\frac{g_{s} \mu_{B}}{\hbar}\right)^{2}|\psi(0)|^{2} \boldsymbol{S}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{S}_{2}
\]

where $|\psi(0)|^{2}$ is the probability of the electron and positron being at the same position. As the 1s state is spherically symmetric, it is easy to compute the expectation value of the terms in brackets as 0 for both singlet and triplet states. The second term in the equation is the Fermi contact interaction, which is non-zero for s-states. The Fermi contact interaction energy is:

\[
H_{\mathrm{F}} =\frac{8 \pi}{6}\left(\frac{g_{\mathrm{s}} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}}{\hbar}\right)^{2}|\psi(0)|^{2}\left(S^{2}-S_{1}^{2}-S_{2}^{2}\right)
\]

\[
=\frac{4 \pi}{3} g_{\mathrm{s}}^{2} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}|\psi(0)|^{2} S(S+1)+\text{constant}
\]

where $S=S_{1}+S_{2}$. By definition, $S=0$ corresponds to the singlet state and $S=1$ corresponds to the triplet state. The energy difference between the singlet and triplet states is:

\[
\Delta E=\langle S=1| H_{\mathrm{F}}|S=1\rangle-\langle S=0| H_{\mathrm{F}}|S=0\rangle
\]

Thus, the energy splitting caused by magnetic interaction is:

\[
\Delta E=\frac{8 \pi}{3}\left(\frac{1}{\pi a_{\mathrm{P}}^{3}}\right) g_{\mathrm{s}}^{2} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}=\frac{4 \mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}}{3 a_{\mathrm{H}}^{3}}=\frac{2}{3} \alpha^{2} R_{y}=5 \times 10^{-4}(\text{eV})
\]

Here, we have used $|\psi(0)|^{2}=1 / \pi a^{3}$. This result matches the one derived from dimensional analysis in formula (2). Therefore, the magnetic field experienced by the electron is:

\[
B=\Delta E / \mu_{\mathrm{B}} \approx 10^{5} \text{ Gauss (using } \mu_{\mathrm{B}} / \hbar=1.4 \text{ MHz/Gauss)}
\]

Positronium also undergoes an "annihilation" process contributing to the hyperfine splitting, with a value of $\alpha^{2} \mathrm{Ry} / 2$, which does not occur in the hydrogen atom.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: A $\pi^{0}$ meson decays isotropically into two photons in its rest frame. If the momentum of the $\pi^{0}$ in the laboratory frame is $p = 280 \, \mathrm{MeV}/\mathrm{c}$, find the relation between the angular distribution of the photons' momentum and the cosine of the polar angle in the laboratory frame. Consider the isotropic nature in the rest frame and the effects of Lorentz transformation.
solution:
In the rest frame of the $\pi^{0}$, the distribution of the decay photons is isotropic, satisfying the normalization condition $\int W_{0}(\cos \theta^{*}, \phi^{*}) \, \mathrm{d} \Omega^{*} = 1$. Since $\pi^{0}$ decays into two photons, $\int W(\cos \theta^{*}, \phi^{*}) \, \mathrm{d} \Omega^{*} = 2$. $W$ represents the probability of emitting a photon into the solid angle $\mathrm{d} \Omega^{*}(\theta^{*}, \phi^{*})$, independent of $\theta^{*}$ and $\phi^{*}$, leading to the integral

$$
\begin{gathered}
W(\cos \theta^{*}) = \frac{2}{4 \pi} = \frac{1}{2 \pi}, \\
W \int \mathrm{d} \Omega^{*} = 4 \pi W = 2.
\end{gathered}
$$

Integrating over $\phi^{*}$ gives

$$
\int_{0}^{2 \pi} W(\cos \theta^{*}) \, \mathrm{d} \phi^{*} = W \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \mathrm{d} \phi^{*} = 1
$$

which results in

$$
W(\cos \theta^{*}) = 1.
$$

If $\theta^{*}$ corresponds to $\theta$ in the laboratory frame, then

$$
W(\cos \theta) \, \mathrm{d}(\cos \theta) = W(\cos \theta^{*}) \, \mathrm{d}(\cos \theta^{*}).
$$

Let $\gamma_{0}$ and $\beta_{0}$ be the Lorentz factor and velocity of $\pi^{0}$ respectively; for photons, from Lorentz transformation we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
p \cos \theta &= \gamma_{0}(p^{*} \cos \theta^{*} + \beta_{0} E^{*}), \\
E &= \gamma_{0} p^{*} (\cos \theta^{*} + \beta_{0}), \\
E &= \gamma_{0} (E^{*} + \beta_{0} p^{*} \cos \theta^{*}) = \gamma_{0} p^{*} (1 + \beta_{0} \cos \theta^{*}).
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the distribution in the center-of-mass frame is symmetric, $E^{*}$ and $p^{*}$ are constants. Differentiating the above equation with respect to $\cos \theta^{*}$ gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\cos \theta \frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta^{*}} + p \frac{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta}{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta^{*}} = \gamma_{0} p^{*}, \\
\frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta^{*}} = \gamma_{0} \beta_{0} p^{*}.
\end{gathered}
$$

Solving these yields

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta^{*}}{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta} = \frac{p}{\gamma_{0} p^{*}(1 - \beta_{0} \cos \theta)} = \frac{1}{\gamma_{0}^{2}(1 - \beta_{0} \cos \theta)^{2}}.
$$

Using the transformation formula

$$
E^{*} = \gamma_{0}(E - \beta_{0} p \cos \theta)
$$

or

$$
p^{*} = \gamma_{0} p (1 - \beta_{0} \cos \theta).
$$

Thus,

$$
W(\cos \theta) = W(\cos \theta^{*}) \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta^{*}}{\mathrm{d} \cos \theta} = \frac{1}{\gamma_{0}^{2}(1 - \beta_{0} \cos \theta)^{2}}.
$$

For a $\pi^{0}$ with mass $140 \, \mathrm{MeV}/c^{2}$ and momentum $280 \, \mathrm{MeV}/c$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma \beta_{0} &= \frac{280}{140} = 2, \\
\gamma_{0} &= \sqrt{(\gamma_{0} \beta_{0})^{2} + 1} = \sqrt{5}, \\
\beta_{0} &= \frac{\gamma_{0} \beta_{0}}{\gamma_{0}} = \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}.
\end{aligned}
$$

The angular distribution in the laboratory frame is

$$
W(\cos \theta) = \frac{1}{(\sqrt{5})^{2}(1-\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \cos \theta)^{2}} = \frac{1}{(\sqrt{5} - 2 \cos \theta)^{2}}.
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Assume a muon decays into an electron and two distinguishable neutrinos. The decay rate for the electron momentum to be between \( p \) and \( p + \mathrm{d}p \) is given by:

$$
\mathrm{d} \Gamma = \frac{2 \pi}{\hbar} \left(\frac{g}{V}\right)^2 \frac{V p^2}{2 \pi^2} \frac{\mathrm{d}p \mathrm{d}n}{\hbar^3 \mathrm{d}W}
$$

where \( g \) is the coupling constant, \( V \) is the normalization volume, \( p \) is the momentum of the emitted electron, and \( W \) is the total energy of the three emitted particles. The lifetime of the muon is \( \tau = 2.2 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~s}, m_{\mu} = 207 m_{e} \). Using this data, calculate the value of \( g \).
solution:
Integrate over the entire momentum range \((0 \leq p \leq \frac{w}{2c})\) to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\tau} & = \Gamma \doteq \int_0^{\frac{Mc}{2}} A p^2 (3w^2 - 6wpc + 2p^2 c^2) \mathrm{d}p \\
& = A\left\{ M^2 c^4 \frac{(Mc)^3}{8} - 6Mc^3 \frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{Mc}{2}\right)^4 + \frac{2c^2}{5}\left(\frac{Mc}{2}\right)^5 \right\} \\
& = A\left(\frac{1}{8} - \frac{3}{32} + \frac{1}{80}\right) M^5 c^7 = \frac{7 M^5 c^4 g^2}{7680 \pi^3 h^7} \\
g & = \sqrt{\frac{7680 \pi^3 (ch)^7}{7 \tau c (Mc^2)^5}} = \sqrt{\frac{7.680 \times 10^3 \times 3.1416 \times 2^7 \times 10^{14} \times 10^{-91}}{7 \times 2.2 \times 10^{-6} \times 1.06^5 \times 10^{10} \times 3 \times 10^{10}}} \\
& = 2.22 \times 10^{-43} (\mathrm{MeV} \cdot \mathrm{cm}^3) = 3.55 \times 10^{-49} (\mathrm{erg} \cdot \mathrm{cm}^3)
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
Both ${ }^{161} \mathrm{Ho}$ and ${ }^{163} \mathrm{Ho}$ can decay into Dy isotopes through electron capture, but the $Q_{\mathrm{EC}}$ values are 850 keV and 2.5 keV, respectively. For ${ }^{161} \mathrm{Ho}$, it is known that the $3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}$ electron capture rate is $5\%$ of the 3s electron capture rate. For ${ }^{163} \mathrm{Ho}$, calculate the electron capture rate of $3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}$ relative to the 3s electron capture rate.

Table 2.11

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
\hline
\text{Orbit} & \text{Binding Energy (keV)} \\
\hline
1s & 54 \\
2s & 9 \\
2p_{1/2} & 8.6 \\
3s & 2.0 \\
3p_{1/2} & 1.8 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
solution:
For $^{161} \mathrm{Ho}$ and ${ }^{163} \mathrm{Ho}$, they have the same nuclear charge and the wave functions of orbital electrons are the same. Their electron capture transition matrix elements are also identical for 3s and $3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}$ orbitals. The only difference is the phase space of the decay final state.

The electron capture decay constant is given by

\[
\lambda \approx A\left|M_{fi}\right|^{2} \rho(E)
\]

where $M_{fi}$ is the electron capture transition matrix element, $A$ is a constant, and $\rho(E)$ is the density of final states. For electron capture decay, each decay emits only one neutrino, representing a two-body decay, where the neutrino is monoenergetic

\[
\rho(E) \propto E_{\nu}^{2} \approx\left(Q_{\mathrm{EC}}-B\right)^{2}
\]

Here, $B$ is the binding energy of the orbital electron in the s or p state. For $^{161} \mathrm{Ho}$, the problem states

\[
\frac{\lambda\left(3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}\right)}{\lambda(3 \mathrm{~s})}=\frac{\mid M\left(3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}\right)\mid^{2}\left(Q_{\mathrm{EC}}-B_{\mathrm{p}}\right)^{2}}{|M(3 \mathrm{~s})|^{2}\left(Q_{\mathrm{EC}}-B_{\mathrm{s}}\right)^{2}}=0.05
\]

Thus, we have

\[
\frac{\left|M\left(3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}\right)\right|^{2}}{|M(3 \mathrm{~s})|^{2}}=0.05 \times \left(\frac{850-2.0}{850-1.8}\right)^{2}=0.04998
\]

For the electron capture of ${ }^{163} \mathrm{Ho}$, the transition matrix element $M_{fi}$ is the same, but the phase space of the final state is different, so

\[
\frac{\lambda\left(3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}\right)}{\lambda(3 \mathrm{~s})}=\frac{\left|M\left(3 \mathrm{p}_{1 / 2}\right)\right|^{2}\left(Q_{\mathrm{EC}}-B_{\mathrm{p}}\right)^{2}}{|M(3 \mathrm{~s})|^{2}\left(Q_{\mathrm{EC}}-B_{\mathrm{s}}\right)^{2}}=0.04998 \times \left(\frac{2.5-1.8}{2.5-2.0}\right)^{2} \times 100 \approx 9.8\%
\]

subject: Atomic Physics
problem: Assume there is a scalar quark \( \sigma \) with spin 0, charge \( Q=-\frac{e}{3} \), and it is a color triplet. Its mass is 5 GeV. Determine the \( J^{PC} \) values for the low-energy bound state of \( \sigma-\bar{\sigma} \), where \( \bar{\sigma} \) is the antiparticle of \( \sigma \). Which states can be produced in an electron-positron collision?
solution:
Firstly, assume the \( \sigma-\bar{\sigma} \) bound state is non-relativistic, and its wave function consists of spatial and spin angular momentum components. The scalar quark has a spin of 0, so the total angular momentum \( J \) is determined by the orbital angular momentum \( L \). Since scalar quarks are bosons, assume the intrinsic parity is \( \eta_{0} \). The particle and antiparticle have the same intrinsic parity, so \( \eta_{0} \eta_{0} = +1 \), leading to the following parities and charge conjugation \( C \) parities for the \( \sigma-\bar{\sigma} \) bound state:

\[ 
\begin{gathered}
P = (-1)^{L} \eta_{0} \eta_{0} = (-1)^{L}, \\
C = (-1)^{L+S} = (-1)^{L}.
\end{gathered}
\]

Therefore, the lowest \( \sigma-\bar{\sigma} \) bound states have \( J^{PC} = 0^{++}, 1^{--}, 2^{++}, \ldots \). To determine which states can be produced in \( e^{+}e^{-} \) collisions, consider a simple and commonly used electromagnetic annihilation process where, in the lowest order, \( e^{+}e^{-} \) annihilate into a single photon, which then transforms into a scalar quark bound state. The quantum numbers of the photon are \( J^{PC} = 1^{--} \), so the produced scalar quark bound state must have the same quantum numbers as the photon, meaning only a scalar quark bound state with \( J^{PC} = 1^{--} \) can be produced. Other states can be produced through higher-order processes, such as radiative decays of the \( J^{PC} = 1^{--} \) state. Scalar quark bound states can also be produced via strong interaction processes, such as in \( p \) collisions, but currently, no direct experimental measurements have been observed.

subject: Atomic Physics
problem:
An important test of modern weak interactions is the scattering of $\nu_\mu$ neutrinos with electrons

$$
\nu_{\mu}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \nu_{\mu}+\mathrm{e}^{-}
$$

At low energy, the effective Hamiltonian for this process is given by

$$
H_{\text{eff}} = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}}{\sqrt{2}} \bar{\Psi}_{\nu} \gamma^{\alpha}\left(1+\gamma_{5}\right) \Psi_{\nu} \bar{\Psi}_{\mathrm{e}}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}} \gamma_{\alpha}+g_{\mathrm{A}} \gamma_{\alpha} \gamma_{5}\right) \Psi_{\mathrm{e}}
$$

where $G_{\mathrm{F}}$ is the Fermi constant, and $g_{\mathrm{V}}$ and $g_{\mathrm{A}}$ are dimensionless parameters. Let $\sigma(E)$ denote the total cross-section of this process, with $E$ representing the total energy in the center of mass frame, such that $E \gg m_{\mathrm{e}}$. Assume the electrons are unpolarized.

Let $\left.\frac{\partial \sigma}{\partial E}\right|_{0^{\circ}}$ denote the differential cross-section in the forward direction in the center of mass frame, expressed in terms of $E, G_{\mathrm{F}}, g_{\mathrm{V}}$, and $g_{\mathrm{A}}$.
solution:
Given that $E \gg m_{\mathrm{e}}$ and $m_{\mathrm{e}} \rightarrow 0$, the lowest order Feynman diagram for $\nu_{\mu} \mathrm{e} \rightarrow \nu_{\mu} \mathrm{e}$ is as shown in Figure 3.23(a). Figure 3.23(b) is a projection diagram in the center of mass frame. Let $p_{1}$ and $p_{3}$ be the four-momenta of the incoming $\nu$ and $\mathrm{e}^{-}$, and $p_{2}$ and $p_{4}$ be the four-momenta of the outgoing $\nu$ and $\mathrm{e}^{-}$. The direction of $p_{1}$ is along the $z$-axis, leading to the following relations:

$$
\left(p_{1}+p_{3}\right)^{2}=\left(p_{2}+p_{4}\right)^{2}=s
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{1}=\frac{\sqrt{s}}{2}(1,0,0,1), \quad p_{3}=\frac{\sqrt{s}}{2}(1,0,0,-1) \\
& p_{2}=\frac{\sqrt{s}}{2}(1, \sin \theta, 0, \cos \theta), \quad p_{4}=\frac{\sqrt{s}}{2}(1,-\sin \theta, 0,-\cos \theta) \\
& \mathrm{d} \sigma=\frac{\mathrm{d} \Omega}{64 \pi^{2} s}|F|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

(see Figure 1)\(\\\)
(a)\(\\\)
(see Figure 2)\(\\\)
(b)

Figure 3.23\(\\\)
The square of the scattering amplitude is

$$
\begin{aligned}
|F|^{2} = & \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\not{p}_{1} \gamma^{\alpha}\left(1+\gamma_{5}\right) \not{p}_{2} \gamma^{\beta}\left(1+\gamma_{5}\right)\right] \\
& \times \frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left[\not{p}_{3}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}} \gamma_{\alpha}+g_{\mathrm{A}} \gamma_{\alpha} \gamma_{5}\right) \not{p}_{4}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}} \gamma_{\beta}+g_{\mathrm{A}} \gamma_{\beta} \gamma_{5}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\not{p}=\gamma_{\mu} p^{\mu}$, and the factor $\frac{1}{2}$ is for averaging over the electron spin, while no averaging is required for neutrinos, which are left-handed.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Tr}\left[\not{p}_{1} \gamma^{\alpha}\left(1+\gamma_{5}\right) \not{p}_{2} \gamma^{\beta}\left(1+\gamma_{5}\right)\right] = \operatorname{Tr}\left[\not{p}_{1} \gamma^{\alpha} \not{p}_{2} \gamma^{\beta}\left(1+\gamma_{5}\right)\right] \\
& = 4\left(p_{1}^{\alpha} p_{2}^{\beta} - p_{1} \cdot p_{2} g^{\alpha \beta} + p_{1}^{\beta} p_{2}^{\alpha} + \mathrm{i} \varepsilon^{\alpha \beta \mu \nu} p_{1 \mu} p_{2 \nu}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, the second term simplifies to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Tr}\left[\not{p}_{3}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}} \gamma_{\alpha}+g_{\mathrm{A}} \gamma_{\alpha} \gamma_{5}\right) \not{p}_{4}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}} \gamma_{\beta}+g_{\mathrm{A}} \gamma_{\beta} \gamma_{5}\right)\right] \\
& = 4\left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right)\left(p_{3 \alpha} p_{4 \beta} - p_{3} \cdot p_{4} g_{\alpha \beta} + p_{3 \beta} p_{4 \alpha}\right) + 2 g_{\mathrm{A}} g_{\mathrm{V}} \cdot \mathrm{i} \varepsilon_{\alpha \beta \mu \nu} p_{3}^{\mu} p_{4}^{\nu}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
|F|^{2} & = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 4\left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right)\left(p_{1}^{\alpha} p_{2}^{\beta} - p_{1} \cdot p_{2} g^{\alpha \beta} + p_{1}^{\beta} p_{2}^{\alpha}\right)\left(p_{3 \alpha} p_{4 \beta} - p_{3} \cdot p_{4} g_{\alpha \beta} + p_{3 \beta} p_{4 \alpha}\right) \\
& = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 4 \left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right)\left(2 p_{1} \cdot p_{4} \cdot p_{3} \cdot p_{4} + 2 p_{1} \cdot p_{3} \cdot p_{2} \cdot p_{4}\right) \\
& = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{2} s^{2} \left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right)\left[4+(1+\cos \theta)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The neutrino reaction cross-section is

$$
\mathrm{d} \sigma = \frac{\mathrm{d} \Omega}{64 \pi^{2} s} \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{2} s^{2} \left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right)\left[4+(1+\cos \theta)^{2}\right]
$$

Integrating over the solid angle and substituting $s=E^2$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma & = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} s}{64 \pi}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right) \int_{-1}^{1}\left[4+(1+\cos \theta)^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} \cos \theta \\
& = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} s}{64 \pi}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right)\left(8+\frac{8}{3}\right) \\
& = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} s}{6 \pi}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right) = \frac{G_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}}{6 \pi}\left(g_{\mathrm{V}}^{2}+g_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}\right) E^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The reaction cross-section is proportional to $E^{2}$. As $E$ increases, the reaction cross-section increases, yielding a higher event count.
